I did it! I have ascended to the realm of people that own a game on Steam that is no longer available for purchase! A pointless flex, but you're here reading a review for a game no longer available on this platform so who's insane now!?

The Story:

You play as a jelly bean that fell into a nuclear reactor and compete against other jelly beans in lighthearted events for the entertainment of your corporate overlords. That's not canon so don't quote me, but seeing as this is a multiplayer party game there isn't much of a story to take part in. So I made up my own. Each round your take part in is referred to as an "episode" so it is obviously designed around the idea of a competitive TV show. 

The Gameplay:

This is one of those games designed to be amusing and not at all to be taken seriously. Similar to games like Human:Fall Flat and Gang Beasts. The physics are designed to be fairly uncontrollable and unpredictable while your avatar is thrown into mini-games designed to intentionally throw a curve ball at those wonky physics creating fun, unexpected and often rage inducing scenarios. 

The mini-games vary and they're adding new ones with each season, but the goal often revolves around taking part in some kind of race, endurance, memory or team related sport. It's chosen randomly each round, and you'll likely not like every event but I appreciate that they try to be innovative and create new game modes. You can compete solo, in duos or in squads of four players. Each mode has a starting count of 60 players and the losers are eliminated until only one player/team remains. 

Some Pros:
- Lighthearted "battle royale" party game. 
- Friendly for all ages.
- Is free-to-play on Epic.
- Is cross platform.

Some Cons:
- No longer on Steam.
- Can lead to controller smashing for you competitive types.
- Micro transactions (optional). Skins, season passes, etc.
- Can get old fast for some.

Conclusion: 

Fall Guys is an adorable game. If you're in the mood for something casual with your friends then this is high up on the recommendations list. Unfortunately to play it on PC now you'll have to hop over to Epic (blegh, blasphemy) but that is a small price to pay if you've been looking for something crossplay to jam with some friends who may not have a PC. Still. Don't let Epic ruin your chance of finding something you might really enjoy.

A whole development team made one of the most simple games in concept and failed so terribly that it's kind of funny.

1. The game is very buggy, such as the placement/qualification system, random teleporting shapes that can knock you off the map, the mantling system only working half of the time, and more.
2. Inputs regularly do not register (tested on multiple different input devices + experienced by other people I know).
3. Made the game free to play and gave the original paid players almost nothing in return.
4. They recently removed almost all opportunity for purchasing items without buying a paid currency.
5. Winning a match feels unsatisfactory, as you don't get enough rewards to justify the effort.
6. Cheaters run rampant. This game has had a cheater problem since the start and they have made minimal progress on fixing it.
7. The netcode is sub-par at best. Every player interaction is janky and laggy regardless of your performance/ping, and it has been this way since the start.
8. The maps are very unbalanced. There are maps that will leave only a couple of people qualifying and maps where almost everyone qualifies, and they are inconsistently placed at different stages of the match which ruins the flow of the game.

I love this game, but I really hate Epic's anti-consumerism. Let people have choices, man, especially if the game first launched on Steam. It would be one thing if Fall Guys released as an EGS exclusive, but it did not, so the game should be on both stores rather than one since Epic now owns Mediatonic.

Furthermore, most people who do find themselves playing this on Epic probably will not pay money for cosmetics or skins, especially since it is a free-to-play game. Epic Games has resorted to use free stuff to entice people to use their store, which is fine, but the problem is that if everything paid isn't as appealing or isn't as affordable as what's on Steam or GOG, then no one will spend money on Epic, and their lawsuit with Apple seems to have proven this theory correct.

Epic, just give people a damn choice.

First and foremost, this only being free on Epic Games Store (you can still buy it for Steam if you get a key and redeem it), is a big downer. The only reason you should get this on Steam is if you want to make sure it's on your Steam profile forever.

Most of this game is just frustration and unfair Wipeout style games. There are some fun gamemodes/playlists, but they're mostly time-limited and not always available. The cosmetics are mostly locked behind the premium currency now that the game is F2P for all other platforms. This is would be fine if there weren't achievements tied to getting a full set of top-tier cosmetics.

The game also doesn't let you leave games after you've lost unless you want to lose your rewards. In team games you can only leave after the wall section where it shows who was eliminated. In solos you can't leave until that same wall section. In team games, if your entire team leaves, you still can't leave until the same point as if you'd lost the team game normally. If your team leaves in team games you are guaranteed to lose in any score related game mode (which is most, if not all) as well because the game won't balance your score for not having any teammates.

If any of the above paragraphs were solved this would probably become a recommendation, but all of these problems together make this not really worth playing.

Epic bought the game. I think it's needless to say why this is bad.

Also, I hate the people on this game, gosh, a crowd of brainless kids pushing you to your dead or just being an obstacle because of how bad they are at playing the game. Needless to say, I hate the kind of game in which your life can depend on some other people's thinking and decision making capacity because most of the time it really seem like they don't have a brain at all, not to talk about the people that purposely make you die on non PvP maps, I hate those guy with all my being. 

Even if you are a skilled player, people can still get you caught up in the crowd constantly, jostled about by forces not under your control and flung all over the place. The whole thing plays like a game of competitive Goat Simulator with more pastel colors, but just as impossible to control. The courses are full of unconsistent and uncontrollable obstacles, which send players flying off in any direction. It is entirely possible for the crowd to carry you into an obstacle, which then sends you flying off the map through no fault of your own. This makes me want to snap my keyboard in half.

In few words, Fall Guys is an entire game based on the premise of people with small brain capacity being in your way, if that's of your liking, get the game, I mean it's free on Epic, but if you are a sane and reasonable person please stay away from this thing.

I love playing Fall Guys everyday. The game has a solo, duo, and 4 player squad mode in which players must complete objectives to qualify for each round. This objectives can include race to the end, survive fall platforms or avoiding being knocked off, or scoring points through hopes or getting balls into the net. At the end of each game you get different rewards, which allows you to customize your character the way you want to. Overall, the game is fun to play a couple hours a day for completing your dailies and weeklies and I would highly recommend anyone to pick this up and add to your steam library whenever you can.

A really fun and goofy multiplayer game. It is a Battle Royale style game but approached in a very different way. There's no looting, no dropping onto the map, etc. As soon as the game starts, you're competing and as soon as you get eliminated you can start again. In my opinion, that always beats the idea of looting for 15 minutes just to get eliminated in a couple seconds. This being said, if you're looking for a competitive BR, this (obviously) isn't the place. The skill cap is pretty low, but that's what makes this game fun; anyone can win/have a good time.

how to make meth : Illicitly manufactured meth is usually made by combining ephedrine or pseudoephedrine with other chemicals that are often poisonous or highly flammable. The mixture is then added to a solvent such as gasoline and heated to crystallize. Because illicit methamphetamine production is not regulated or supervised, and there is no quality control process, any number of cutting agents could conceivably be added to the process to dilute the drug.

The heating process is particularly dangerous, as there is significant risk of fire and explosion. The waste materials left behind are also highly unstable and combustible. According to the U.S. Forest Service, 1 pound of meth produces up to 6 pounds of toxic waste.

There are many detrimental health effects associated with operating a meth lab. Inhaling fumes during methamphetamine production can cause significant lung damage and other respiratory issues, while handling the various corrosive or poisonous chemicals can damage the skin and eyes.

While the core gameplay is still as fun as it was back in 2020 when Fall Guys released, I can't bring myself to recommend it after what Epic has turned it into in regards to earning cosmetics, which is the whole other half of the game, as well as the technical issues they caused when introducing the new "cross-save" system.

Everything used to be reasonable to earn and you couldn't even buy the high end currency, you had to earn it (challenges giving shards helped make that better as well) and even Kudos had some worth as they could still get you pretty much any items other than the Legendary and some Epic cosmetics in the store.

Now, nearly all items cost a new "premium" currency, Kudos has next to no value as you can only use them on common items which they offer only a hand-full of at a time, Crowns have basically zero value as you can't even spend them and they are just another battle pass, and items that you already own have been reduced in value (quite literally) to the point where a ton of legendary items are now just labeled "special" and don't count towards legendary item achievements anymore.

Also, the season passes cost 2,800 show-bucks and only give back 1,800 upon reaching level 100 so they don't even earn you enough back so you can afford the next season's pass like many other free-to-play games do as a reward to completing it. The free season pass only gives 300 show-bucks for level 100 by the way.

To top it all off, myself as well as thousands of other legacy players who have been playing since well before this new shift into free-to-play and actually spent money on this game had all of our account data deleted due to Epic's absolutely abhorrent new save system that doesn't even bother asking which account you want to set as your primary before wiping all of your old data to replace it with a brand-new save so have fun waiting for customer support if you didn't know to log in after the update on whatever version you want your progress from because they couldn't put in a simple "Do you want this to overwrite your old data?" upon logging in.

Even if you do get your data properly situated, there is no real cross-save as they claim to have. The only thing it does is sync your achievements and it even messes that up. No items, currency, or progress of any kind syncs across platforms so don't bother playing on two different versions because if you earn something on one, the other won't get it.

Also they de-listed this Steam as well as the original PlayStation versions, the latter soon to lose the ability to be played at all so good luck getting every trophy before that happens.

For players like us who've spent money on this game and played it while it was actually good, it's really hard to see what it's become immediately after selling out to Epic and taking up the F2P model. While they did give legacy players a few small items and the first new season pass for free, it feels even more like a slap to the face as all of those items should be easily obtainable by all players by simply playing the game. I know the game probably wasn't doing very well financially but I honestly would have rather seen the game's legacy go out in a heartwarming fizzle than to watch it slowly suffer the painful death it seems to be on the road to. Shutting the game down and moving on to other titles or maybe adding the option for offline play/P2P multiplayer and then shutting down the dedicated servers and leaving players to their own devices would have been a better fate than this.



TL;DR - Epic has sullied the reputation of this game and potentially the developers along with it. I hope Mediatonic got quite the check from this deal. I would say to not buy this, but they won't even let you anymore.

Played this game on and off since December of 2020. It was a great innovation seen within the gaming industry. A fun party game to enjoy with friends with an active dev team aspiring towards a road map of constant new updates. A game without in game currencies for microtransactions, decent prices for bundles ($5) and a way to progress to unlock everything excluding the 5 dollar bundles. It was no perfect game, but the in game progression was perfect in my eyes in comparison to other games in the industry. Now comes along Epic Games to steal the life out of this game and dying community so they can cash out on little kiddies using their mother's credit card. They COMPLETELY implemented the currency system used in Fortnite and to some extent removed the ability to get those items for free without  having to pay money or for returning players, grinding the hell out of the BP, which will in return only give you 1500 "show bucks". A halo bundle that comes with 3 low quality skins will cost you roughly $20. You can buy the Halo MCC for $16 dollars with the steam sale in comparison. You already know some kids and whales are going to buy the hell out of this, and most likely nothing will change. First Epic Games ruins Rocket League and then they ruin Fall Guys. When Epic Games first purchased Rocket League they claimed nothing would be changing. That turned out to be a lie, Not only did they destroy the trading market but they also dropped mac and linux support for the game with no refunds for players on those respective platforms. Epic Games killed Rocket League. They even made it so you can no longer see how many players are in a given playlist, only "good" or "great". I feel they did this because they are embarrassed that nobody plays that game anymore so they don't want anyone to know how many people are actually playing it anymore. Epic Games is anti consumer. It's disgusting to see Epic Games pay developers to take their games off Steam but with it happening to Fall Guys most recently, I don't think they plan on stopping anytime soon. In Fall Guys you used to be able to get cool cosmetics such as Scout from TF2 and Cuphead by just playing the game. Epic Games changed this, now you can only get these cosmetic items by spending real life money in the game. Mediatonic allowing Epic Games to do this to their game shows they lack integrity and I cannot respect them. Tim Sweeney, you are never gonna beat Valve. These anti consumer practices are only gonna hurt you in the long run. There is gonna be a point in the future when people move on from Fortnite and PC gamers do not forgive or forget as easily as you may wanna believe. Thanks for ruining Fall Guys

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Okay Epic, let's do some maths...

The average battle pass tier takes around 600 fame points.

With these laggy ass Epic servers, you can barely qualify 2 rounds each time you play, which makes it around 60 fame points per game played.

To get a tier you need 10*60 fame points, and you need 100 tiers in total.

That makes 1000 games to get to max tier... 1000 games!!! Are you out of your mind?

I barely hit 1000 matches on my favourite most played games. I won't force myself through a 1000 games of Fall Guys just to get my money back from purchasing this game back when it was paid!

We have to work ourselves through over 1000 games of laggy servers before the season ends just to get what we paid for in the first place. 

Another great example of Epic's stupid business decisions right here. Thank you for forcing me to play your laggy game for over 1000 matches just to complete the pass that you forced me to have for my money. Really appreciated...

Fall Guys is a casual game that can be played by all who enjoy platform games. With practice it can be mastered!
I have been enjoying each new season of this game upon release. Certainly the gameplay gets repetitive after a while, but it's worth coming back for the new content! I have laughed endlessly seeing beans fall in the most stupid ways. The skins available are creative and can be purchased with in-game currency, although one can use irl cash to acquire them.
That said, the fact the publisher has closed its relationship with Steam is a bit shady to me, as it forces folks to turn to a different platform. I still recommend the game regardless for the fun of it though.

Fall Guys was fun when it first came out but the devs showed very little care and consideration for it, letting it stagnate rather than adding interesting content and fixing the bugs (primarily related to lag and desync). Two years later they have now pulled it from Steam and made it F2P. I understand the F2P approach for a dying game but the devs really dropped the ball here and rather than attempt to claw back their playerbase with good content they are hoping F2P just magically revives the game. If you're reading this consider installing it on Epic don't bother, it's fun for a while but gets old fast. The lag and desync is infuriating in the final rounds of games too.

UPDATE SUMMARY :
They turned the game into a cashgrab by making currencies you get from playing useless.

General Details : 
They have a paid season pass now which is fine but even progressing through it seems impossible because of the reduced fame you get now from winning/losing rounds. But dont worry you can skip through tiers by paying not even with kudos but with show-bucks( game's in-game currency acquired only with real money). The shop is a total cashgrab now. If you only have kudos you can only buy like 5 bad quality cosmetics which by they way refresh every 5 days or so. So the possibility of getting a skin you like is almost down to zero.On the other hand the shop is filled with skins you can buy ...yeah you guessed it with show-bucks.The only currencies you can get from just playing or even winning are worthless and old players like myself lost their crowns and got kudos...useless.

Conclusion :
But the gameplay is free whats your problem man? The biggest problem is that winning does nothing now. The game doesnt reward play time at all . Just spend money and you get what you want. Its a shame honestly .

Game sucks if you want to win

While I love the gameplay loop and playing with friends is great. The F2P model is dreadful for legacy players. Crowns being converted to Karma is kind of an insult. While it would of been fine for the last payment model. Once this went F2P, the game locks all the great cosmetics now behind the RMC. So all the crowns that got converted into Karma will get you basic cosmetics.

The servers and stability has been off since it has gone F2P. Team modes have been consistent of spawning within' each other and being on the wrong side of teams. I don't know if this is intentional, but it really needs to be fixed.

Overall, I have to give this a 'Eh' review. I really wish their was a mixed review for Steam since that would be my final verdict. But I am going to have to trend towards a Negative Review for this game as it currently stands.

game was great until F2P update. im fine with most of the changes (skill based matchmaking, console players etc), love the new levels, but the introduction of show bucks makes the game feel pointless now. Before, you win and got crowns, which could be used to get the cool costumes in the shop. Now, wins are only useful in large numbers, for the crown rank that you unlock every couple dozen of crowns. all the costumes cost show bucks, and i'm a third of the way through the battle pass with like half a costume's worth of them.

severing the link between actually playing at the game and getting costumes makes playing the game feel pointless. i would be fine if wins gave you even a tiny amount of show bucks (like 10-20 when costumes are 800), but they don't. i have hundreds of hours in this game, and im sure a large percentage of them were playing specifically because i wanted enough wins to buy a costume. this incentive is gone, crowns are barely useful, kudos still have little to no worth (which makes converting crowns to kudos instead of show bucks frustrating), and every skin costs like 800+ show bucks. its just extremely frustrating that such a fun game has become so unrewarding.

Fortnite and PlayerUnknown’s Battlegrounds may have popularised the last player standing format, but Fall Guys: Ultimate Knockout has truly unlocked its potential by painting it hot pink and putting it in a hot dog costume. Mediatonic’s family-friendly formula is a colourful, bouncy breath of fresh air that takes a different, less explosive approach to battle royales without losing any of the tension. Instead of C4, it’s Vitamin C you’ll be steering clear of as you’re bombarded with monstrously overgrown oranges in just one of its two dozen game show-like events. The vast majority of these minigames hit the mark, offering fun and frustration in equal amounts. Couple them with a vibrant aesthetic and a brain-tunneling soundtrack and Fall Guys manages to make you want to punch the air when you’re winning and scream at your screen when you’re losing, but you’ll be laughing either way.

The concept of Fall Guys will be familiar to those that have seen game shows such as Wipeout or Takeshi’s Castle. Guide your very own customized jelly bean avatar through up to five rounds of inflatable carnage and you’ll have a shot at taking home the crown. Each match is framed as an episode and lasts around 15 minutes at most, which further drives home that TV show feel. The controls are simple with running, jumping, diving, and grabbing as your only tools to navigate obstacle courses, avoid enemies, or cling on for dear life in more survival-centered events that threaten to plunge you into the slimy depths. If you do happen to get eliminated then you have the option to watch those remaining battle it out for the title while the musical equivalent of glycerin is poured into your ears. A game show is only as good as its games though, and this is where Fall Guys’ current pool of 24 largely triumphs. The obstacle course-style races are where I’ve found the most enjoyment, especially as it gets down to the wire as beans bounce off one another and desperately lunge for the finish line trying to make the cut.
I’ve been particularly enjoying the havoc of Hit Parade and the precarious spinning platforms of The Whirlygig, which often descend into chaos as twenty too many characters try to fit through a small gaps or all jump for the same narrow platform. There’s always more than one path to take, some offering a high risk-reward option, which is welcome as it never feels like you’re completely out of a race despite being near the back of the pack. In Door Dash you hurtle towards the bottom of a track attempting to dive through doors, some of which will blast open, whereas others will stay firmly shut. There’s a simple pleasure found in walking through an opening as the opponent next to you slams face first into a brick wall. But games that rely on silly physics can often take as much as they give, as seen in See Saw, which varies from the other races in that it can become incredibly frustrating almost instantly. The whole course consists of multiple enormous seesaws, funnily enough, and largely relies on your fellow competitors understanding how these playground apparatus made for toddlers work. It’s baffling how very few of them appear to, as you’ll find yourself sliding off their hopelessly titled platforms again and again due to, you know, basic physics. Then there’s Slime Climb, which is notably more difficult than most and served as my nemesis for many of my early hours playing Fall Guys. It’s a real sorter of the wheat from the chaff as slime slowly rises and you battle the clock, your opponents, and a mountain of obstacles. While most events usually cull Fall Guys’ initial pool of 60 players by about a quarter to half each time, it wasn’t uncommon for only a handful of players to be left after this event. But there is nuance to master here, and I soon found myself able to succeed where I once so often failed, now able to consistently conquer the climb and no longer audibly groaning when it appears in the rotation.

That said, there are no offline modes in Fall Guys currently, so that mastery only came out of a lot of online losses. There’s no practice area to get to grips with the two dozen events, but more crucially there isn’t any scope for local co-op. It feels a bit of a miss to not have the option to play split-screen or against the AI in your own private matches. Most of the fun I’ve had with Fall Guys has been when playing with friends, whether that be cheering them on once I’ve already been eliminated or laughing at them as they get hurled into the abyss thanks to a 20-foot long banana. What’s a party game without a healthy dose of schadenfreude, after all? Another small but similar disappointment is the limit of a maximum of four players to a party, which is the only way to ensure you’ll enter the same tournament together. I can only think how fun it would be to have a lobby largely populated with people you know battle it out for the crown. With this in mind, the option to create your own custom matches and playlists would be the feature right at the top of my wishlist for the future. Another reason for this being so desirable is that while most events are highly enjoyable, some Fall Guys rounds, well, fall flat. These include Perfect Match, an all too simple memory game that results in very few eliminations and – most criminally of all – is just a bit boring when compared with the mayhem found elsewhere. Any of the rounds that include the ‘tail tag’ mechanic can become an exasperating affair. At their core, they require you to chase opponents around an arena and grab their tails from them. This can often become an exercise in futility, however, as the grab mechanic often doesn’t latch on to them unless you’re very close, and getting very close is a challenge due to the fact that you are moving at the same speed as the tail’s current owner. It’s disappointing that this mechanic is recycled in three separate games, especially when one of those is among the three ‘finals’ events meant to be the climactic end to a match. It can really take the wind out of my sails to see Royal Fumble as the crowning event after fighting hard to get there. Then there’s team events. When partied up with friends these can be the highlight of an episode as you work together to achieve your goals – quite literally, in some cases, as you can play bitesize games of soccer. Conversely, they can be the most infuriating part of Fall Guys if your team members are not pulling their weight. I understand that this is a risk with playing any online team game, but it feels at odds with Fall Guys’ free-for-all nature at times when you’re left helpless as a teammate scores another own goal. Thankfully any frustrations are soon forgotten if you manage to get that all important crown at the end. Whether that be quite literally grabbing it at the summit of the frantic race finale Fall Mountain or being the last left standing on the disintegrating geometry of the surprisingly strategic Hex-a-Gone. There’s a distinct sense of accomplishment and pure joy that the best battle royale games give you when grabbing a victory, and that feeling is the clearest sign yet that Mediatonic has got it right with Fall Guys.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well.

for those who don't know, epic games is trying to compete with Steam because Steam is taking an absurd 30% cut from the developers revenue, while Epic Games is only taking 12%.
Epic Games even said they will put Fortnite on Steam if Steam will lower the cut they are taking.

Games should be supportive of Epic Games' initiative, more revenue for developers means more and better games, while more revenue for Valve means absolutely nothing.

[H1]So what's it about?[/H1]
Think Squid Game but colourful and happy. Or think Takeshi's Castle. You're a fall guy and your mission is to finish first through different kind of obstacles course.

[H1]The good[/H1]
It's colourful, the level design is great and the music is cool.

There are a lot of unlockables although all of them are just cosmetic: the fall guy you start with had the same speed and abilities as the one at level 50.

It's friendly multiplayer - no toxic community! Even when you lose (which will happen a lot) it's still a fun experience.

Since the update you can now cross play with other players on other systems.

[H1]The not so good[/H1]
Since the update the game has become more like a mobile game: F2P with cosmetics that are more expensive than the previous DLCs :-(. 

The progress system (well just to get more cosmetics) is now behind a pay wall. If you want that new cool costume be prepared to pay. 

The season pass is grindy and it's not rewarding to complete. 

You now need to have a separate login for Epic Games even though you purchased the game on Steam.

[H1]Summary[/H1]
Fall guys is a cute and simple game that is great to be played with friends. If you don't care about progress, season passes or expensive cosmetics then go for it (although you can now only get it on Epic Games as the Steam version only exists for those who purchased the game). However if you get annoyed about different F2P tactics in tempting to get you to spend more money on one outfit than what the original game cost just look for something else.

As a buyer of the game I feel I have not been treated well: I got a season pass which is grindy and some ugly cosmetics. Other than that I'm just considered a F2P player and will fall in the same category as anyone else. But I guess in the end it's just business with little emotions involved: F2P might be more financially successful so the existing player base doesn't matter anymore. With this in mind I can't recommend the game.
It is fun but when I loose I want to smash my keyboard.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Once again, Epic Games sticks their greedy fingers into anything they can get their hands on. Their recent overhaul monetizes the hell out of the game, and they've screwed over long time players.

1. You're no longer able to get rare skins through playing the game alone, you now have to pay. The free currency (that was already a decent grind to get) can only be used to buy common stuff now.

2. Previously, crowns were typically used to purchase rare skins. They were only obtained through high placement, or very slowly through leveling. Now that crowns have been removed, there is far less incentive to actually grind and get good at the game.

3. Skins that used to be event exclusive are now being sold in the shop, which is unfair for anyone who had them.

4. Old legendary color skins are now common/rare, which is also unfair for those who had them.

It's been a good run, but I'm through with this game. There's literally nothing to play for anymore. I cant even finish the last achievement on my steam list without forking out cash, even though I ALREADY BOUGHT THE GAME.

I hated Epic Games with a passion before this, and somehow they continue to find ways to remind me to keep hating them.

This game is fun but with many minor annoyances. It is a fun party game that is surprisingly difficult to win despite being so simple. The season pass does what any season pass is supposed to do and encourages you to keep playing and doing well. It is not a new mechanic by any means, but the amount of rewards you get for how good you do feels very balanced, and encourages you to do good. Unfortunately, many of the minigames are frustrating and boring, and it is not randomized well, and you will do the same one often. Also the load times are awful, it takes so long to find and load into a game, and if you lose quickly you have to wait forever just to try again. Overall it is a fun game, but you will end up waiting just as much as you are having fun.

This game is cute, has a variety of customizable features for your fall guy which are earned, is kid friendly, and you're able to play with friends. I have yet to figure out how to play with only 2 people an no one else, but it does have a 'squad show' that allows you to be in groups of 1-4 with a total of 60 people in the show. Certain shows are more challenging than others and they are not all races. Some have you stay within a certain zone for a percentage of time, others have you pop bubbles and at least one of the shows challenges are to avoid getting kicked out by rhinos. Sometimes it seems like certain shows get repeated a bit too often which is a bit frustrating if you want more variety or simply don''t care for that particular one. Unfortunately this game has froze up on more than one occasion (for me and my friend). Overall this game is fun and family friendly but it can be repetitive and is definitely not a game for those with motion sickness.

Pre-F2P, I wholeheartedly recommended this game. I didn't mind purchasing it because the in game economy felt fair, items were unlocked at a generous rate, earning currency wasn't too much of a grind, and the prices in the store were reasonable for most items.

Post-F2P, there are some problems. The currency has been severely nerfed. Crowns are now worthless aside from gaining Crown Tier prizes, Kudos used to be given out generously, but are now given out at a much slower rate. Of course, you can purchase premium currency, but the exchange rate is pretty bad.

Despite some disappoints with the recent changes, I recommend Fall Guys. At the end of the day, the game is still fun. And now that it's F2P I can play with my kids across Xbox, Switch, and Steam. I can't complain too much.

[b][i]I HATE YOU, EPIC GAMES. MAY YOU ROT IN HELL.[/i][/b]
Fall Guys used to be my only solace during the first wave of the COVID pandemic, when I lost my grandmother. It was a tough time and all those hours I had spent with three of my best gaming buddies [i]@Schrödinger's Cat[/i], [i]@M0rty[/i] and [i]@Error 404[/i]. Those were some of the most genuine, fun and rewarding hours of my life that saved me from sinking into depression.

Over the last year, since Epic brought out Mediatonic, they have stripped the life out of the game and then "legally" stole the game from Steam to their abominable platform with:
[olist]
    [*]zero capabilities of social interaction
    [*]in-game microtransactions with real money (f2p my foot) for the beloved cosmetics
    [*]rarity downgrade for the existing legendaries and still somehow having the head-turner trophy
    [*]crowns being non-spendable, kudos being spendable on common items only
    [*]fame decrease per show making the season pass an absolute chore
[/olist]

There is [b]ZERO[/b] incentive to play this game any more.

Epic, you guys irreversibly ruined something many gamers like me loved very dearly with an abject lack of accountability.
You would forever be responsible for the downfall of this game and may no good thing ever come your way, Tim Sweeney.

I didn't know that I had made an Epic Games Account, nor that I linked it to my Steam account. I actively avoided their greedy, anti-consumer hands this far. Even when they bought up and delayed games I had wanted to play for years I patiently waited as to not support their practices with my money.

When I launched Fall Guys today it automatically installed Epic Games software on my computer without my permission, I was then supplied with an account created by Epic Games without being asked or even given the option to decline or choose username.

It seems it's not enough to divide the PC userbase years after Valve had more or less single-handedly saved the PC gaming industry, to buy out devs and publishers and force consumers to use your storefront. Now Epic has gone so far as to make these publishers remove their games from pre-existing markets years after their release. If you bought the game on Steam, you can't play it on Steam. You have to use their services now.

This is disgusting, and a new level of anti-consumer. If only TotalBiscuit was still with us, perhaps we wouldn't have let things go this far. But as long as Epic keeps making money doing things like this, they will only get worse...

Fall Guys : Ultimate Knockout used to be an extremely fun game to play with friends on weekends.
The fact that most cosmetics could be bought with an in-game currency that was awarded to you for completing specific quests was really entertaining and kept the game as f2p as possible. You could however spend money on the game if you wanted some extra goodies.

And then there's Epic Games. The dudes that made Fortnite. Just like they did with Rocket League, they bought this game (and the developer studio) and pulled it off of Steam. Booting the game now, you can immediately notice that alot of microtransactions were added (e.g. skins and bundles sold for money, new useless currency that most of the cosmetics are sold for) along with changes to some mechanics of the game. First of all, they made it so that you cannot buy the season pass unless you complete it. Not only is this frustrating but it's also a tactic to get the most gameplay time off of a person.

Just like Rocket League, this game will probably die within 2 months because of all the useless economy changes made. Epic always had a jealousy for VALVe. And always will. They're trying to become VALVe and replace Steam with their own game shop. The thing is that bribing will only lead to your downfall. I really hope this game dies so that Epic can realize how much of a monster they really are and possibly lose money.

Story:
None

Gameplay:
Very basic but fun. The last level is where everyone races for the crown is a annoying, however. You can play near perfect in the last level but never get the crown or it can be luck base if it's the maze.

Sound:
It's really fun. Cute music although the menu music can be loud and annoying. Sometimes the music doesn't play due to a glitch.

Overall:
Epic bought it and now it's horrible. They forced you login to Epic accounts and use them,removed it from the Steam store, and force you to pay for any desirable skin with real money and it's very expensive. The seasons are no longer free anymore, you have to pay for a season pass. You use real money to buy fake Fall Guys currency called Show-Bucks *cringe*. Half of the fun with this game was earning random items, and now that that was taken away, this game has lost its value. I'm sure less people will care about playing this game now. The Fall Guys I bought no longer exists anymore.

Before this free for all update. i would have happily recommended fall guys. I loved it. i loved playing it despite my frustrations with players grabbing me. but that's part of the game. what's no longer part of the game is my drive to play like i used to. with Epic games having sunk their greedy claws into this wonderful game it's turned into quite spectacle. items that used to cost crowns from hard earned victories now cost show bucks which are unsurprisingly at not so reasonable prices per item. and to compound those matters. you can't even earn kudos anymore through regular play! only through what seems to be the season pass and whatever. Im glad i hung onto the crowns i had when they decided to convert them to kudos. but it's pretty clear the use for kudos is now about as helpful as a rhino charging into you on stomping grounds.

That aside. it's still the same fall guys gameplay. just with more aggressive monetization. but not immoral levels of it. just... a level of it that saddens a longtime player used to how things once were.

I just have no words to describe how bad the development of this game has been. Its a shitshow, first it was ravaged by hackers then it took 8 months to update a season and get new content and now that it became free2play its even worse, the currency for which you got skins got converted to a the currency form common items ( which are like colors and stuff mostly pretty boring stuff)  and everything else is paid for like 10 euros a skin? Theres nothing to gain in this game other than skins and now you have to pay for? Plus they added a paid season progression on top of it? Yesterday the matchmaking system was not working and today i got and error that doesnt give me even the meager rewards the game now gives you. The rewarding currency even in 1st place is so low that i wasnt even bothered that i missed it i was bothered because it doesnt even work. Fall guys deserves 0 money and all the bad reviews they could get, its like a reverse no mans sky were they seek every effort to make the game worse each passing day. I guess you could still have fun with no rewards if u like the Castle of Takeshi kind of concept but even that requires that the game will work properly again any day now with an update that fixes it, since its free now its okay to get it i guess just dont expect to get anyhting out of it.

It's free now and popular. Ok, now that I have stated the good stuff, here's the bad.

 Old players that had crowns (currency via winning) were turned into kudos (typical round by round currency). All the good stuff in the past you could buy with crowns buy winning are only purchasable through new currency. This new currency is only gathered via the battle pass or irl money.

TDLR: If you are playing this game & new, play it with friends and only spend money if you want to look cool. Don't expect to look like sonic or godzilla without spending cash or lots of hours. We paid for two copies of this game a long time ago, and when we heard it was going free-to-play, we were expecting that money would not go to waste. We were pleasantly surprised to see costumes and free season-pass access for season 1.

Then at the very end of the rewards part, there was a message telling us that all of our crowns would be turned into a woefully inadequate number of kudos, because they changed the entire monetization system.
It presents itself as such:
Showbucks are for costumes, emotes and generally the cool stuff. You get some as you rank up in the free part of the battlepass-like season progress rank.
Kudos are for colors, patterns, items, and generally the boring stuff.

On average, costume prices seem rather high for how many you get, and the fact that the crowns were just removed is a little baffling. Especially with the mediocre offering in kudos given that the kudos buy garbage.
A fair trade would have been crowns for showbucks, in a 20-50 showbucks per crown ratio.
Instead they ripped us off by monetizing the crap out of this game and going free-to-play, and my girlfriend cannot stand the changes made. 

I'll be very clear: I paid for this game. No change to this game will get me to pay ANY more. Personally, I won't be touching this game again. My girlfriend may be a different story, and she'll give the game a chance, but she refuses to pay another cent. If she gets gated from content or the game dies, she doesn't feel bad for ditching it. Compensate us fairly for the crowns, severely drop your store prices (before any idiot uses their mom's credit card), fix the wait times (a byproduct of a good game), and encourage people to return rather than finding ways to exploit them for money.

Clearly the exclusivity deal with Epic was all about the money, and not at all about the quality or longevity of this game.
At least if the game got better, it would have covered up the obvious desperation for cash.
What annoys me most about this is that this game was her favorite. Being someone who plays games casually, that is a very difficult spot to win. While she used to love the game, she's not even sure if she still likes it anymore. What went wrong?
At the request of the publisher, Fall Guys is no longer available for sale on Steam.

Once again, Epic Games sticks their greedy fingers into anything they can get their hands on. Their recent overhaul monetizes the hell out of the game, and they've screwed over long time players.

1. You're no longer able to get rare skins through playing the game alone, you now have to pay. The free currency (that was already a decent grind to get) can only be used to buy common stuff now.

2. Previously, crowns were typically used to purchase rare skins. They were only obtained through high placement, or very slowly through leveling. Now that crowns have been removed, there is far less incentive to actually grind and get good at the game.

3. Skins that used to be event exclusive are now being sold in the shop, which is unfair for anyone who had them.

4. Old legendary colour skins are now common/rare, which is also unfair for those who had them.

It's been a good run, but I'm through with this game. There's literally nothing to play for anymore. I cant even finish the last achievement on my steam list without forking out cash, even though I ALREADY BOUGHT THE GAME.

I hated Epic Games with a passion before this, and somehow they continue to find ways to remind me to keep hating them.

I bought this game a year or so ago, but didn't start playing it often until a few months ago. Before it was made free, I would have recommended this game to anyone, however, since the update on June 21st, AKA making the game free, I cannot say I would recommend this game anymore, especially to old players looking to switch to new platforms, or simply re-buying or revisiting the game. The new achievement and currency system is a copy of Fortnite, so if you like that, go for it I guess. But for the players looking to get away from the battle pass you have to pay for as a new player, the new update of fall guys takes that away from you. Now, the creators are simply trying to get money from people, luring them in by making the game free and then convincing them to buy the Fall Guys equivalent of V-Bucks. I now wish I hadn't bought this game, as I don't see myself playing it anymore with the new changes that I attempted to stay away from when leaving the fortnite battle royal game. 

However, if you love fortnite and if you are ok with buying a battle pass every season to get any fun cosmetics, this game is for you. Luckily, now that the game is free, you can test it out yourself before buying the battle pass, but be aware of its addicting nature. This game will NOT stay free for long, as if you keep playing, youll eventually spend your money on something.

Roast Sausages and Vegetables Recipe

If you’re not a fan of chopping and frying for hours then this recipe is the one-tray wonder you’re looking for. This recipe can also use of lots of your leftover vegetables and herbs so feel free to experiment with timings when cooking those.

Ingredients Serves:

Pack of large Sausages

500g Sweet Potatoes, chopped

One Broccoli head

2 Red Onions, sliced

3 Mixed Peppers, chopped

1-2 Tbsp Olive Oil

Sprinkle of mixed herbs

Method
Preheat oven to 200℃/ Fan 180℃/ Gas Mark 6.

Pour 1 tbsp of olive oil in a roasting or baking tray and place in oven for 5 minutes.

Meanwhile, chop the sweet potatoes and mixed peppers. Place the sausages, sweet potatoes and peppers in the baking tray. Toss in the oil and roast for 15 minutes.

Add the sliced red onions to the tray with a sprinkle of mixed herbs. Toss with the sausages and veg and roast for a further 10-15 minutes.

Meanwhile, cook the broccoli in a pan of boiling water for 5 minutes. Drain and serve with the sausages and veg.

Another game getting thrown head first into the dirt thanks to Epic's Fortnite kid profits. First Rocket League and its trading economy becomes horrible due to Epic buying the developers and now Fall Guys is getting the same treatment; all fuelled by their jealousy towards Valve.

Fall Guys, just like Rocket League, is getting removed from Steam. Essentially getting 'bought off' of the Steam Store.

Tim Sweeney really needs to get over his Gabe Newell envy. It's just screwing over the customers and their freedom of choice, it's not making things better via bribing or out-right buying developers just so you can forcefully remove games from Steam or prevent them from ever releasing there in the first place - or for a limited time like the recent Final Fantasy 7 Remake bribe money they gave to Square Enix to delay release on Steam for half a year.

Keep your 'console war' type mentality as far away from PC gaming as possible, Epic. You're a bunch of sellouts who mostly abandoned PC gaming back when Gears of War became popular. Now you come running back after companies like Valve, old Blizzard and various Indie studios revived the PC gaming market.

Epic Games are making Electronic Arts look like a better gaming company by the minute...

Yeah game's great. Got a third party steam key as a gift because good sale and it's going away tomorrow, as of the time of writing, but yeah the game's great. If you own it you get a founders pack when it goes free to play, and I think that's a pretty good reward for getting the game early. Imagine Takeshi's Castle, but with dubious little creatures (beans) getting up to mischief. What, you didn't grow up with Takeshi's Castle? Well that's quite sad, but it was a good show. Contestants would go through a set of games, consisting of obstacles, until there was one winner left. I guess another example would be Squid Game, where they also have to play some games until there is only one winner left. Only with Squid Game they only get depression and don't feel good for winning the prize earnings. This game has it's own prize earnings consisting of 'Crowns' that you obtain through the seasonal passes, or by winning the final game of a match. If you did watch Takeshi's Castle and enjoyed it, I think you'll enjoy this game very much, especially since it's going free. Although with it going free, you won't be able to buy it on Steam anymore, but all the others platforms will have it, so it isn't the end of the world, just sad.

I think the game has a lot to offer but it is not the same as before epic games bought it up. I used to play this game when it cost to play it and I found it fun due to the variety of mini-games and the rewards (crowns and Kudos) you earned which could be spent in the item shop to get emotes and other cosmetics. Then after Epic Games bought it up, they added a new currency (Show-Bucks) which are very hard to get without spending money, although Kudos is still in the game crowns have been completely removed as a currency and Kudos allows you to buy very little from the item shop. Basically, Epic Games has added a fall guys alternative to V-Bucks which has made the game much more based around spending money than playing the game to develop.

As most players, even I'm not happy with Epic Games taking over this game, doesn't matter if it's free on Epic.. I enjoy being on Steam! I would not even have a problem with Epic Games if they did not pay a ship load of kwan to some game companies to make their games exclusive on Epic stores, but since that's the case, I personally don't support that. Many are there who do and it's their choice, but I'm only voicing my own opinion, whether it matters or not, that does not concern me and should not concern anyone. 

This game is fun to play, no doubt, I'm genuinely happy for those who wished to play this game and will now be able to without paying a dime. I like to play this game when I don't feel like doing too much especially when I get home after work. 

If I've offender any Epic sympathiser, I apologise. I understand that there are many who do wish to buy games and Epic does their weekly free games thingy which is genuinely a good thing, heck, even their sales are great, but making a game store exclusive is in my opinion, unjust. Especially when it comes to a franchise, all the older entries will be here (Steam) but the newer ones of the same franchise won't be... that's just sad. 

The game overall is an 8/10, happy gaming folks!

Tumbling gentleman, is the most rage inducing experience i have ever witnessed. The game itself infuriates me, as a sigma male standing at whopping five foot four ; with the knowledge that these ridiculing whipper-snappers are six foot tall, i have no other emotion to embrace other than pure fury. These squishy, bouncy, 6 foot tall demons are contrasted with vibrant colours and hues of rainbows, i believe this colour palette of pain was intended to ease the eyes, however this only fed the flames of my anger ; it did not assist in any way that the music is almost as painful to listen to as the colours are to look at, it was like listening to a choir from hell.

sincerely, an infuriated gamer.

6/11/2021: Other than the 392 hours I currently have (which I know will continue to go up), I also have put in a little over 1,000 hours on my wife's PC (I just got a pc for the first time in the last year). I'd say that Fall Guys is definitely a great game to check out if you're looking for something goofy and colorful to occupy your time. A warning to anyone new who wants to give it a try; it might take you a *long* time before you're finally able to win a round. And that's ok! Just keep giving it your all and you'll get there eventually. The physics can be a bit unforgiving at times though, as a second warning. A great game to play with friends too!

Look, I really like like this game, but with the new update they are going to release, I am not sure about that anymore. One of the most fun part in Fall guys was the fact that you got all skins just by playing. It was so rewarding to buy a whole lot of skins. You could get a skin after playing a few round. Now they are going to force us to pay money for those skins. I think it really is a shame that they have to squeze every last dollar out of the players. This beatiful game was one of the last games, where you didn't have to pay to look good. In my opinion the game should stay at a price of 20 Dollars, and not be free to play. I am quite sure, that most of the players would enjoy the game more if it was a one time purchase. This game is becoming another example of the the modern day game industry. The developers of the game (Epic Games too) just develop the games to make money. It limits the fun that the players will have so much.
Furthermore, I think the players should just keep all the skins they have already buyed by playing the game! I just don't see that point, that Epic Games deletes all the skins in the inventory of every player. They just want us to buy more of their skins, but now for real money instead of the ingame currency. But I will say, that I surely won't do that, and I hope that none of the other players will.
Instead of rewarding the players that played since launch, that payed for the original game, they just demotivate them to further support and play the game. I think that in the long term, the game will just lose in popularity. As much as I like the game, in my opinion, that sadly will be the truth

Imagine this: it's a Friday night and a caring mother, me, wants to take her kids somewhere special after their soccer practice.  I started the evening expecting only the most exquisite experience at my local Chili's diner.  What I got was a horrible dinner session that me and my children will remember for the rest of our lives.  It started normally, though proceeded in a completely different direction.  The Chili's staff and crew members greeted us immediately and sat us down at a nice booth in the middle of the restaurant.  I talked to my kids about practice for a while before the staff was "so kind" to bombard me with a series of questions including, "What drink do you want?" and "Are you ready to order yet?".  This situation really brought down the dining experience for me personally.  But that's not all.  When the food FINALLY arrived, it was only WARM!  I feel offended that the staff thought this low of not only me, but my beautiful sweet peas.  Don't get me wrong, I'm not writing this 1 star Yelp review to bring down the entire company, I'm only writing this for the betterment of the Chili's restaurant and staff in the future.  I fully believe if they try their hardest, this company can soar to new heights.  Yet, for now, I don't think I'll come back anytime soon.

-Princess Karen <3

DO NOT BUY FALL GUYS. At the end of the current in-game "season," the game will be delisted from Steam's store, so you can only get it on EGS. It's going free-to-play, replacing the current progression system with the same "one free line, one paid-season-pass line (also all the cool stuff you want is on the paid line)" crap that Fortnite poisoned this medium with. It's still all cosmetics as far as I know, so at least there's that.

I'm not requesting a refund, because I don't think that's a valid form of protest in this case. I definitely got my money's worth of enjoyment from Fall Guys. Demanding a refund for this game isn't going to stop them from making it bad by slapping a predatory monetization scheme on it, and refunding even three-quarters of its existing players would still amount to pocket change for a company as big as Epic. If you dislike the direction this game is taking (which you should) and want to make a statement against what companies like Epic are doing to the game industry, remember that as a consumer, [i][b]knowledge is power.[/b][/i] Tell your friends how they ruined this fun, silly Wipeout battle-royale game. Explain how season passes can be (and usually are) used to create a gameplay loop that psychologically manipulates players into unhealthy spending habits. Get them thinking about how much games are worth to them, mentally [i]and[/i] monetarily, so they can weigh the costs against the benefits. Tell them to tell [i]their[/i] friends, too.

everyone's throwing a fit that fall guys is becoming f2p and being moved to the epic games store

guys, you paid $20 for like two years of access to this game. epic is even compensating you with exclusive items and access to the first "battle pass" or whatever they called it. look at what epic acquiring rocket league did, it went free to play and nobody had a problem. the game was booming with players compared with the old two minute queue times. this exact thing is happening with fall guys. a knock-off called stumble guys is doing better right now. they're free to play, have a "battle pass", and even got accused of having a crypto-miner in the game. y'all don't like epic because they're a "monopoly", they run the exact same business. y'all were dick-riding epic games when they gave out large and interesting titles for free. but now that they're not feeding you with good free games, y'all are bashing epic. i owned this game originally on PS4 and bought it on steam in-case it turns out that keys for this game skyrocket (i also wanted to get some steam achievements). epic knows what they're doing, just calm down. all this game has on steam is achievements (which will probably also be migrated to epic games with their new achievement system rolling out), you can always manually add fall guys to steam to run it under proton (for the linux gamers). also, you shouldn't be throwing fits over having to use an epic games login. it's just a simple account. if you're still throwing a fit over fall guys going f2p, just remember all the hours you put into the game and all the fun moments you've had prior to the announcement. if you don't have any, you didn't truly play this game.

please note that i'm not saying epic is a perfect company, they do have some flaws. like the fact that they don't have their own "workshop." i also hate their affiliate/support-a-creator program. it's only useful if you play fortnite, they don't give any docs related to integrating it into games and they refuse to put it into any games other than fortnite and rocket league (i'm hoping they put it into fall guys tho).

tl;dr: i see this as a great opportunity for fall guys to revive. if you still cry about fall guys going f2p, you never actually enjoyed the game and don't understand the place fall guys is in right now. and people who despise epic games need to get a life and realize that everything they're using involves some type of "huge and unfair" monopoly. get the game if you want to collect it or if you still think epic games is a "stupid monopoly", i cannot change your mind. just keep in mind that it's going f2p on June 21st.

Nowhere was it stated when I bought this game that I would eventually need an Epic Games Store account to play it.

This product no longer works as intended due to fundamental changes made by the developer. While they claim you can still launch the game through Steam, this is a false claim as you are now directed through the Epic Games Store. This, as well as other changes, affects the way this game functions on Linux.

Although, by US law, I am legally entitled to a refund regardless of play time, the Steam Refund process is no recourse, as the requests are clearly not being reviewed by an actual human. Mediatonic maintains that no one at their support team is capable of contacting Steam Support in order to make an exception, and have my refund issued, but this is a blatant lie.

If a completely obscure individual named Steve from Rocket League Support was able to contact Steam Support and assist me in receiving a refund for their game that I had bought four years prior, and do so in just two short emails, there is no plausible explanation as to why Mediatonic cannot do the same; the idea that Steam support would be any less accessible to Mediatonic than they are to Psyonix is an excuse that falls flat on its face when you consider that, not only are you selling on the very same storefront, but you are now owned by the very same company.

Okay, so I'm glad I revisited this game, because in the earlier days of it I did think that they had a shortage of game modes. But a few seasons later, this game has definitely levelled up!

A quick rundown of the game for those unfamiliar or debating whether to pick it up, Fall Guys involves taking on a lobby of roughly 60 players in a competitive, almost game-show-like "show", compromising of a series of randomised race/survival/points rounds. There are now a range of really fun gamemodes that are all easy to understand for new players, but can get quite ruthless as the lobby shrinks down. And the roster of gamemodes only expands each season!

Customisation in the game is phenomenal. There are some AMAZING outfits that can be unlocked, a fact that was true even at the beginning of this game's time but has only become more true as the devs have worked with many license holders to create so much customisation! The store system is very reminiscent of other Epic Games' titles like Fortnite and Rocket League, whereby the store regularly rotates content. I know that might annoy some people, but all new outfits are always made available for a few days at least. 

There is also a battlepass - however as I am typing this that pass is COMPLETELY FREE (this may be subject to change, more on that in a sec!). The length of time you get to finish this pass is pretty generous (I easily finished the recent one by doing dailies here and there), and the cosmetics are usually pretty good quality! Plus it should give you sufficient currency to buy some of the store cosmetics as you please!

Currency is also earn by playing, and playing better obviously rewards more XP, Kudos, and (if you WIN) Crowns! There is certainly no "pay-to-win" and most of the better cosmetics are primarily unlockable using the unpurchaseable crown currency. So ultimately, you shouldn't need to pay money to bling yourself out!

Now, some of this MAY change given that the game is becoming FREE TO PLAY! Epic Games owns Fall Guys, and I believe it is scheduled to be free over on EG as of the 21st of June. But while we obviously dont know how this will affect currency gain and store layout, the game is still at its roots really fun, and should have a reasonable playerbase to make it last. I would recommend, at the very least, picking it up when it becomes free. If you want to pick it up now to take advantage of the DLCs and legacy pack, I would also recommend it.

(P.S. Prime Gaming has also featured skins each month and sometimes currency too, so if you have that, take advantage!)

It's pretty fun, although that fun has been slightly soured by Epic's acquisition of Mediatonic and the fact that the game will be removed from the Steam store. While EAC support has been (technically) enabled for linux (including SteamOS), that support requires workarounds that are unlikely to be solved now that said acquisition and said store removal. If you ever want to play Fall Guys on linux, you [i]have[/i] to own the game on Steam, because EGS doesn't support Linux or the Proton EasyAntiCheat Runtime.  
If that doesn't worry you and you don't mind downloading another launcher, then by all means, wait for it to go free-to-play on EGS. That said, I would like to encourage you to not buy any in-game items, as to not support Epic's toxic practices in the gaming industry. If Epic wants people to use their platform, they should make it desirable, rather than buying out studios and paying for exclusives.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but at least I can give you strawberry cheese cake recipe.

ingredients:

250g digestive biscuits
100g butter, melted
1 vanilla pod
600g full fat soft cheese
100g icing sugar
284ml pot of double cream
For the topping
400g punnet of strawberries, halved
25g icing sugar

STEP 1
To make the base, butter and line a 23cm loose-bottomed tin with baking parchment. Put the digestive biscuits in a plastic food bag and crush to crumbs using a rolling pin. Transfer the crumbs to a bowl, then pour over the melted butter. Mix thoroughly until the crumbs are completely coated. Tip them into the prepared tin and press firmly down into the base to create an even layer. Chill in the fridge for 1 hr to set firmly.

STEP 2
Slice the vanilla pod in half lengthways, leaving the tip intact, so that the two halves are still joined. Holding onto the tip of the pod, scrape out the seeds using the back of a kitchen knife.

STEP 3
Pour the double cream into a bowl and whisk with an electric mixer until it’s just starting to thicken to soft peaks. Place the soft cheese, icing sugar and the vanilla seeds in a separate bowl, then beat for 2 mins with an electric mixer until smooth and starting to thicken, it will get thin and then start to thicken again. Tip in the double cream and fold it into the soft cheese mix. You’re looking for it to be thickened enough to hold its shape when you tip a spoon of it upside down. If it’s not thick enough, continue to whisk. Spoon onto the biscuit base, starting from the edges and working inwards, making sure that there are no air bubbles. Smooth the top of the cheesecake down with the back of a dessert spoon or spatula. Leave to set in the fridge overnight.

STEP 4
Bring the cheesecake to room temperature about 30 mins before serving. To remove it from the tin, place the base on top of a can, then gradually pull the sides of the tin down. Slip the cake onto a serving plate, removing the lining paper and base. Purée half the strawberries in a blender or food processor with the icing sugar and 1 tsp water, then sieve. Pile the remaining strawberries onto the cake, and pour the purée over the top.

Perfection

let me tell you the story of a boy called little timmy tencent

little timmy tencent was upset that all the other children were playing with the popular kids in his class, who all owned the latest toys and gadgets

he saw them all having fun and he was angry, so he paid some of the kids to play with him for a little while

'this is great', he thought, surrounded by newfound friends, 'now everybody will love me'

it wasn't long before his newfound friends had already run off to the popular kids, playing with even newer toys, laughing and enjoying themselves, and little timmy was furious

'why did nobody have fun with me? what am i missing?' he thought, paying even more of his classmates to play with him and only him, telling them that the most popular kid in his class, who was called gabe, was mean

and despite this, they took little timmy's money, and they kept running back to his classmate gabe when they got bored

and little timmy wasn't happy at all, so he spread some nasty rumours about how his classmate gabe was using his influence to keep some of his classmates from playing with anyone else

but nobody would listen to little timmy

his classmate gabe had everything a child his age could've ever dreamed of

and little timmy had nothing

My previous review criticized the announcement of the game going into F2P, and how many of the advertised changes just altered the outlook of the game from something casual where you'd play the game, gain currency according to your skill and collect cosmetics to a prediction of something along the lines of a grind to be able to gain any cosmetics with little incentive to win. I am glad to inform this isn't the case. It's much worse.

I'll go point by point over my previous review, to see how things have changed:
[b]Update frequency:[/b]
Its literally been 2 weeks since the new Season started its true i asked for more content but I'm not asking them to die over adding new stuff. I will update this in the future.

[b]Currency:[/b] 
If only you knew how bad things really are. 
Crowns, a currency gained for winning games, are gone and are instead downgraded to be an XP system for crown ranks, a long investment cosmetic unlock. With long investment, I mean I've been playing this game since launch, top played hours on my friendlist, average skill tbh and I'm not even 10% done with it. 800 wins for a nickname is just insulting. Separating costumes by 300-500 wins is even worse.
Kudos, the free currency, have been reworked into this "drip fed" currency where you can only get 200 of daily, compared to before where just playing would give you ~250 average [i]per match[/i]. Kudos items have also become very scarce, very unattractive and honestly overpriced for what they actually are. Having to wait a week to get a bowler hat or a fanny pack feels like spitting on the face of your free players, taunting them by showing the cool paid items first in the shop.
Show-Bucks are the new currency in the shop, acquirable by purchasing them for eye-gouging prices or by getting them through the Fame Pass (battle pass), where free players get 300, while players who purchase it get to buy the next pass and have 550 to spare. When the cool looking costumes cost 1200. So I need to save up for 6 months or fork over 20 dollars (!!!) to be able to purchase a single costume, when previously winning a couple of times was enough to guarantee the purchase and any future one.
Dev's gotta eat I suppose 🥴

[b]Epic Store move:[/b] 
So the game is off Steam and its available for free on the Epic Games Store! That means a lot of players have joined in from there!... No, really the best influx of players are consoles, which I see a lot more than people playing from PC. So the move hasn't really done anything for Epic other than make them lose a potential playerbase and more money-I mean customers to support their barebones store. If anything I saw more people purchasing the game on Steam before the switch so that's probably where most of the revenue came from.

[b]And some extras...:[/b] 
What did they do to this game? In the 2 weeks I've played since the new update I've experienced more bugs and game breaking issues than in my previous 2 years of playing this. Rounds where the game freezes for you, where spawns are in the wrong locations, where you're thrown into uneven versus games, games where it just boots you out to the splash screen because "a critical error occured" while everything was working fine... I understand porting to consoles is a big ordeal but that's why you have a porting studio helping you with development, so you can focus on the content and fixing while they focus on getting the game working on other platforms.

So why am I focusing SO much on cosmetics being paywalled? Because that's actually half the game. The first part being the funny bean game where you jump and fall and that's fun, that's mostly intact, it SHOULD be, nothing was drastically changed on that side. The reward system that comes from performing well in the games however is busted, to the point that losing on the first round over and over nets you more experience than actually playing the game to the finals. There's no incentive to win, which WAS the points of the cosmetics, if anything completing your Daily/Weekly challenges now are of most importance, which most of the time involve just playing the game more than trying to improve on your abilities, to be able to actually have a decent chance of completing your Season pass or levelling up your crown rank. Free to pick weird and fun looking mix and match beans are no more, plain colored beans with normal boring accessories are the norm now, and I couldn't be more sad about it.

This game will no longer be purchasable from Steam on June 21st as it becomes Free-to-Play on the Epic Games Store.
If you do not want to use their platform, make sure to purchase the game before that date.

[b]Fall Guys: Ultimate Knockout[/b]
Developer: Mediatonic
Publisher: Devolver Digital
Type: Battle Royale Platformer
Difficulty: Easy
[hr][/hr]
[b] Review [/b] 
[hr][/hr]
Fall Guys is a fun, kid-friendly platformer battle royale, which might just be the first of its kind! However, this game is delisted from all major PC storefronts, and the developers are adding "premium" paid currency and fame passes and making it impossibly difficult to earn non-premium currencies (fame & kudos). Even then, the new cosmetics you can unlock with kudos are not even worth playing to earn them. Until these horrible additions are dealt with, I will not be playing. Shame on you, Mediatonic.
[hr][/hr]
