Ok, this has been driving me crazy for seven movies now, and I know you're going to roll your eyes, but hear me out: Harry Potter should have carried a 1911.

Here's why:

Think about how quickly the entire WWWIII (Wizarding-World War III) would have ended if all of the good guys had simply armed up with good ol' American hot lead.

Basilisk? Let's see how tough it is when you shoot it with a .470 Nitro Express. Worried about its Medusa-gaze? Wear night vision goggles. The image is light-amplified and re-transmitted to your eyes. You aren't looking at it--you're looking at a picture of it.

Imagine how epic the first movie would be if Harry had put a breeching charge on the bathroom wall, flash-banged the hole, and then went in wearing NVGs and a Kevlar-weave stab-vest, carrying a SPAS-12.

And have you noticed that only Europe seems to a problem with Deatheaters? Maybe it's because Americans have spent the last 200 years shooting deer, playing GTA: Vice City, and keeping an eye out for black helicopters over their compounds. Meanwhile, Brits have been cutting their steaks with spoons. Remember: gun-control means that Voldemort wins. God made wizards and God made muggles, but Samuel Colt made them equal.

Now I know what you're going to say: "But a wizard could just disarm someone with a gun!" Yeah, well they can also disarm someone with a wand (as they do many times throughout the books/movies). But which is faster: saying a spell or pulling a trigger?

Avada Kedavra, meet Avtomat Kalashnikova.

Imagine Harry out in the woods, wearing his invisibility cloak, carrying a .50bmg Barrett, turning Deatheaters into pink mist, scratching a lightning bolt into his rifle stock for each kill. I don't think Madam Pomfrey has any spells that can scrape your brains off of the trees and put you back together after something like that. Voldemort's wand may be 13.5 inches with a Phoenix-feather core, but Harry's would be 0.50 inches with a tungsten core. Let's see Voldy wave his at 3,000 feet per second. Better hope you have some Essence of Dittany for that sucking chest wound.

I can see it now...Voldemort roaring with evil laughter and boasting to Harry that he can't be killed, since he is protected by seven Horcruxes, only to have Harry give a crooked grin, flick his cigarette butt away, and deliver what would easily be the best one-liner in the entire series:

"Well then I guess it's a good thing my 1911 holds 7+1."

And that is why Harry Potter should have carried a 1911.

[u]Original Review:[/u]
Contrary to the people whose sole purpose in life is to reply to every Fall Guys tweet with "dead game," I can tell you it is definitely not a dead game. Personally, I can get into a game within a minute at most, though I know it will depend on region. The game probably isn't for you if you get frustrated easily and/or rage a bunch. It can have issues with lag and body-blocking (bean-blocking), along with skewed distribution of stages (seeing the same rounds way more than others). It's important to note that as of Season 6 the game requires linking with Epic Games, which isn't ideal, but not surprising since Mediatonic has been acquired by Epic Games.

I like playing the game, and I think it's fun to play with others as well. The beans (fall guys) are really adorable too. The supposed Fall Guys lore is quite silly, believe or not, a fall guy is apparently around six feet tall (⊙_⊙;)

The game was fun. Emphasis on was. The game needed to keep getting content to keep being engaging. At first, it was working as updates were well paced for the season rewards and new content balance, with midseasons being awesome small content boosts. You will most likely get bored of playing after a while, but it's pretty enjoyable for when it isn't boring. 

However, the engagement isn't the main reason why I can't recommend the game, it's mediatonic itself. They focus too much on memeing around on social media and riding on the fame they unexpectedly got (and deserved at the time) for this game. They used to care about the community but now all they do is go on twitter, make basic memes or tweets, make "new" playlists, and challenges which are impossible to complete in fair timeframes. There is a lot of basic fixes to prevent exploits, a lot of issues with network, etc etc. The list goes on. The solution to levels messing up or some levels not being as enjoyable is essentially removing them from the game for months. This wouldn't be nearly as bad if it didn't take over half a year to update and add new content to the game. The new season can only be fun for so long, especially with how little in comparison is really getting added. 

I really liked this game but for these reasons, I just can't recommend it to anyone who isn't looking for a few 10 or 20 hours of fun. It's the kind of the game that really wants you to play it for hours, but it just doesn't work. 

That being said, the game is still pretty fun when it is fun and working and has a lot of potential. If only they were able to release updates more frequently and squash bugs and listen to their community more.

If you love cute characters, intense competition, and shoving people into a cloudy abyss, this is the game for you.

Pros: Harder than you imagine. Short games mean little time commitment. Great system of progressing through item collecting. Good variety of levels there are to play in.

Cons: Getting disconnected from the server.  That may just be my internet speed but its the biggest con of the game. Also, waiting for the correct number of players to be found per round feels like half your time in the game is spent waiting to play. The waiting stinks because you lose your pace. Squad races mean you have to hope that your team mates are set on winning like you. Some play squads just to let their team down.

1/2 cup unsalted butter, melted and HOT

1 tablespoon cooking oil, (olive oil or coconut oil are fine)
1 1/8 cup superfine sugar, (caster sugar or white granulated sugar)*
2 large eggs
2 teaspoons pure vanilla extract
1/2 cup all purpose (or plain) flour
1/2 cup unsweetened cocoa powder
1/4 teaspoon salt

Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C).
Lightly grease an 8-inch square baking pan with cooking oil spray. Line with parchment paper (or baking paper); set aside.
Combine hot melted butter, oil and sugar together in a medium-sized bowl. Whisk well for about a minute. Add the eggs and vanilla; beat until lighter in colour (another minute).
Sift in flour, cocoa powder and salt. Gently fold the dry ingredients into the wet ingredients until JUST combined (do NOT over beat as doing so well affect the texture of your brownies).

Pour batter into prepared pan, smoothing the top out evenly. (OPTIONAL: Top with chocolate chunks or chocolate chips.)
Bake for 20-25 minutes, or until the centre of the brownies in the pan no longer jiggles and is just set to the touch (the brownies will keep baking in the hot pan out of the oven). If testing with a toothpick, the toothpick should come out dirty for fudge-textured brownies.
Remove and allow to cool to room temperature before slicing into 16 brownies.

After playing the game for 80+ hours (as of the time of writing), I felt like giving my thoughts on the game would be great for other people looking to purchase this game.
The game is fun, very fun in fact. I know that some complain about the game being too competitive, but once you play enough, you can be good enough to conquer even some of the most seasoned veterans.
Playing with friends is a blast, discussing the game and encouraging each other makes for some fun times.
The game is very vibrant and the graphics fit the art style very well.
If you do not like how Epic Games Accounts were brought into the game, and made mandatory for players to play, then it is not worth it for you to purchase this title. Personally, this functionality never bothered me, and I enjoyed having my own name, but to each their own opinion, and in mine, I would say the chances of the account linking being removed is very unlikely.
I can say with certainty that this is one of my favorite games of all time, and if you enjoy multiplayer, battle royale, and platforming games, then this game is definitely for you. I can not give my thanks to the developers enough for making, what is in my opinion, a fantastic video game.

Perfect Pancakes recipe

Ingredients:

1 ½ cups all-purpose flour
3 ½ teaspoons baking powder
¼ teaspoon salt, or more to taste
1 tablespoon white sugar
1 ¼ cups milk
1 egg
3 tablespoons butter, melted

Directions:

Step 1
In a large bowl, sift together the flour, baking powder, salt and sugar. Make a well in the center and pour in the milk, egg and melted butter; mix until smooth.

Step 2
Heat a lightly oiled griddle or frying pan over medium-high heat. Pour or scoop the batter onto the griddle, using approximately 1/4 cup for each pancake. Brown on both sides and serve hot.

[strike]This game has been desecrated for corporate greed under the guise of appealing to a wider audience. There is no incentive to play or win the game anymore, unless you plan on spending money. 

Instead of receiving crowns as a way to purchase cosmetics in the shop, you don't get any of the new premium currency, or even kudos, just XP, which doesn't even matter anymore because unless you plan on buying a season pass every time, the XP will do nothing.

There is currently no way to get cosmetics without spending money, as opposed to the previous model which, while slow, still allowed you to get cosmetics from the shop without paying.

The new payment model for the premium currency is also predatory, as most of the costumes cost 1200 Showbucks, which the lowest purchasable amount of Showbucks is 1000 at $7.99.

This means to even get one cosmetic set you need to pay at least $15.[strike/]

Fall guys ultimate knockout, where do i begin.  such an interesting game that may seem simple at first but hard to master.  Although you might find yourself making it past the first 2 rounds or even 3, but try making it to the final or even winning on a consistent basis.  You will probably find that it is much harder to win than on your other multiplayer "battle royale" if you will like fortnite or pubg.  On this not it may seem like I would have a negative attitude towards the game but it is quite the opposite.  It makes it an extra challenge and that feeling when you finally do get a win, oh boy is it amazing, like an orgasm from an absolute ten at the frat party you banged last weekend, I know you get so much poon!  Anyways I digress.  I would give this game a 90/100 for the fact that is so easy to get into and have a great time with the fun loving graphics and sounds you really can't go wrong with fall guys.  The only reason I would take away points as after awhile you may find yourself playing the same maps quite a few times.  Thanks.

Loaded up the game since its been a while...
Please sign into steam, ok.
Load up fall guys.
Please sign into Epic... ok??
Epic, please sign into one of the following... ok nintendo account.

I'm uninstalling.

Just let me play without this garbage.

[b]/!\ Beware, you now need an Epic Games account to play the game.
I'm very displeased with this sudden change that I find to be fraudulent. When I buy a game, I check what I will require to give and what I will receive... it's not so the rules can completely change in my back! Because of this I can't play anymore the game I paid for without making an account I absolutely refuse to be forced to create in these conditions.[/b]

In any case, this game can be fun but also really frustrating.
It's hard to get good/practice/experiment because you get pushed around a lot (maybe a solo/private lobby mode would help with that? => Ah actually from other reviews it seems they have added that, nice).
In party modes, you often are with people that will leave in the middle of a match. So you will be left alone while still being expected to mark points like you are a full team, dooming you to fail.
It was fun at first when discovering the maps but then it feels really repetitive because it seems like you are always playing the exact same thing. They change modes from times to times but if you're playing in the same week then you will mostly play through the same 3 maps and that quickly gets really annoying.

My view of this game wasn't very positive because of these frustrations but I was willing to play it more and give it another chance when I would have more time. But now I can't anymore because they made account changes while I was away. So I guess I'll just have to go with this short review.

When I first picked up Fall Guys, I wanted to love it. The design of the characters was cute, the design of the game world was similarly charming, the music and sound effects were bombastic and enjoyable. The gameplay itself was challenging but in a way as to reward people who practiced and got better. At the end of the day, Fall Guys never fully hooked me. It was mediocre fun with a lobby full of friends, and that is pretty much the best thing I can say about the game. I always felt that I was never really in control of my character, which really sucks when the game is based around jumping puzzles and tight platforming. This could certainly be a product of my own inexperience, but nonetheless reflects poorly on the game. The whole thing, a few hours in, feels like a cheap cash grab that really should have been a F2P game more than anything else. The fact that the developers sold out to EGS is really the final nail in the coffin.

I guess the glizzy skin makes up for all of that though, at least that's what my friends say.

My best friend bought me this game and I love it so much. I've played over 100 hours on this game now so thought I'd leave a positive review. It's super fun to play and the different rounds are really exciting and can be changed-up every so often with new rounds. I have become a bit obsessed with trying to collect the different colours, patterns, face palettes and the different outfits which you can mix and match if you don't have the full set! I think the fact the game is so customisable is one of the best things about it. I also really like the art style because it's super cute and can be addictive, but not too much so I can safely play it during my University time without taking me away too much from my work. It's the perfect balance for me - and it's even better played with friends, but I also like solo play. 


***EDIT: Since the Season 7/Season '1' update Fall Guys became 'free for all', the game has become a bit rubbish. I used to really enjoy playing this with my friend but we've both had enough. The creators have added lots of lovely costumes and designs into the game, except they only reward people who pay real money for items that once were obtainable simply by playing the game and earning in-game currency. However, the quests now give you so little that it is unrewarding and hence, less fun. I was once a collector of the different skins and costumes but now this has become almost impossible unless I am rich. I also feel that there should have been some warning to the original player base that crowns would be turned into kudos, which are basically now a useless currency in game that can only get you mediocre headgear and footwear. The maps are still fun, but I don't play it anymore because I feel like the creators have ruined it for me.

Cheesecake recipe
Ingredients:
- 1 3/4 cups Honey maid graham cracker crumbs.
- 1/3 cup butter, melted.
- 1 1/4 cups sugar, divided.
- 3 (8 ounce) packages Philadephia Cream Cheese, softened.
- 1 cup Breakstone's or Knudsen Sour Cream.
- 2 teaspoons vanilla.
- 3 eggs.
- 1 (21 ounce) can cherry pie filling.
Directions: Mix graham crumbs, butter, and 1/4 cup sugar: press onto bottom of 9-inch springform pan
Beat cream cheese and remaining sugar in large boul with mixer until blended. Add sour cream and vanilla; mix well. Add eggs, one at a time, beating on low speed after each addition until blended. Pour over crust. Bake 1 hour to 1 hour 10 minutes or until center is almost set. Run knife around rim of pan to loosen cake. Cool before removing rim. Refrigerate cheesecake 4 hours. Top with pie filling before serving.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

Fall Guys is a casual multiplayer party game in which up to 60 players compete in several different minigames, with players being eliminated after each round. The "Main Show" as the game calls it, usually consists of 5 rounds, with the final round deciding the winner, who takes the crown. Besides the Main Show, there are usually a couple different side shows every couple of months, which have special rules (like minigames from the same type, be it races, team games, whatever), and the game also gets big season updates at least a couple of times throughout the year, which are usually themed and add new minigames.

I must say, however, that I haven't really played the game since Season 2, before the Epic buyout, but even back then, I found the game really fun, if frustrating at times. I recently got back to it because of one of the special events, and after getting 100% completion, I feel it was time to give my review. The game is still enjoyable, and there's lots of customization options available, though in order to get them, you must earn either of the game's currencies: Crowns, which are earned for winning games, and Kudos, which are earned for playing (and can be bought). While it's great to have such levels of customization (plus several DLC packs adding new costumes), I must say the focus on the game's "economy" (which isn't really an economy, as you can't trade with other players) feels ridiculous, with several cool items being time limited, with no real clue as to when they'll come back, if they come back. This is a great disappointment, as you might miss out on a cool costume just for not playing the game during a specific event, or because you didn't have enough crowns. All in all, its customization aspect has a big FOMO aspect to it.

Then, there's also the subject of the Epic buyout. As I write this review, I'm uncertain as to whether I should give it the thumbs up or thumbs down. The game itself, leaving the "economy" aside is pretty fun (if, again, frustrating at times), but ever since the acquisition, Epic has been integrating it more and more into their system. While the added crossplay capabilities are a positive, having to use yet another account when I bought the game on Steam is annoying (though I did have an Epic account from before they even started the EGS), and it's especially annoying when the game won't work because of a problem with the EOS servers (like when a new Fortnite update comes out).

Anyway, getting back on track, graphically speaking, the game looks colourful, the visual style really emphasizes the sillyness of the games, and the voices of the beans, which mostly talk in "woos" add to the fun. The soundtrack is also very good.

Well, this is one of those times in which I wish Steam would let us use a "no thumbs" score, as there's certain things that make me not want to give a thumbs up to this game, but at the end of the day, and for as long as it remains on Steam, I guess I can recommend it.

EDIT (May 16th, 2022):

Changed my review to a thumbs down because, as I'd suspected ever since the acquisition was announced, the game is going F2P and EGS exclusive next month. While I don't really have an issue with paid games going F2P, I do have an issue with Epic's approach to "competition", which in this case means "buy the developer of a popular game and remove it from the store where it originally gained popularity". It's a real middle finger from the hypocrite known as Tim Sweeney.

It's a party and kind of Battle Royale game in which 60 players compete in mini-games/elimination rounds against each other until 1 man is left standing. All players are awarded in-game currency based on their performances. The currency is then used to buy cosmetic items for one's character from the in-game store, which rotates its store deals daily. The vibe of this game is goofy, yet the gameplay can become surprisingly frustrating as the little character you control moves can be "very" clumsily.

The game is a fun time killer, but I don't think it would hold a gamer's interest for the long term. This multi-player game, unfortunately, does not support voice or text chat, which is a MAJOR LET DOWN for any multi-player game. Without it even with the friends, you made during the game it feels like playing with bots sometimes. The game makes you use taunts but I don't think anyone cares about them at all. So I'd recommend this game before but playing again feels like it's behind his "Battle Royale/Party age" it's like using arrows and swords during the 21st Century...But I respect other people's opinions as well. Until next time see you soon.

This is a MMO, 3D platformer, party game in which 60 players compete in mini-games/elimination rounds against each other until 1 man (or 1 team) is left standing. All players are awarded with in-game currency based on their performances. The currency are then used to buy cosmetic items for one's character or name tag from the in-game store, which rotates its merchandise daily. The appearance & vibe of this game is very light-hearted & goofy, but yet the gameplay can become surprisingly frustrating as the little character you control moves as clumsily as a toddler. 

The game is a fun time killer, but I don't think it would hold a gamer's interest for long term, unless that person has a tendency to be a collector, aka: a loot hoarder. This multi-player game, unfortunately, does not support voice or text chat, which is a MAJOR LET-DOWN for any multi-player game. Without friends to group up with & a 3rd party app such as Discord to provide voice chat, your communications with the other 59 random players are limited to the in-game taunt animations, which people tend to ignore. 

If you have friends who already own this game, the purchase will definitely be worth it if you guys play regularly with a 3rd party voice chat app to cheer or heckle each other. Otherwise, the replayability of this game will be dependent on how much of a loot hoarder you are.

So what is my personal take on Fall Guys as of today? Let me just start by saying that I still absolutely love Fall Guys and the experience is still as enjoyable as it has been. Though there are some things I want to discuss based on how the game has become today.

Let me start with the positives
------------------------------------
* The new games in Season 1 FFA are absolutely amazing and extremely creative! Even the added aesthetic of a cheering audience in the background is such genius!
* I do like that there is an even bigger Battle Pass with now 100 Tiers to get. It really expands what all you can get during the season.
* While getting things like Fame & Kudos aren't really a thing for just playing games, I do like that the addition of more challenges rewards even more Fame, Kudos and Crown Ranks makes it so you do feel more rewarded.
* Fall Guys is now available on Xbox and Switch which is something that has been much anticipated for a while and I am definitely happy for those who can now experience Fall Guys for free as well!
* Since I originally bought the game on Steam, I do appreciate that I got a cool legacy pack with some pretty cool items along with the first Season Pass for free!

Now with the negatives
----------------------------
* I'll start by saying that most if not all of these won't really be attacking Fall Guys or Mediatonic as I'm more looking towards Epic Games with these negatives.
* I'm not really fond of the whole idea of (Show-bucks). Especially since you need to pay for them and use them to pay for Battle Passes. That is the downside of Fall Guys being FFA since there are even more micro-transactions.
* I don't really like that Battle Passes will no longer be free since I know the original idea of FG was for all Battle Passes to be free indefinitely. But of course that was before Epic started working on the game.
* The new store is not really the best also. Yeah there are still skins, colors, nicknames, and plates you can buy with Kudos. But the new skins just seem to be simple Head and Feet cosmetics. Want to get bigger skins? Got to pay with Show-bucks. That downright sucks since I used to enjoy being able to pay for skins with Kudos or even crowns!
* And why get rid of crowns as well? Sure I get that in some capacity they still sort of exist. But now it's just a crown rank. Crowns are no longer a currency in game. 


So that is my take on Fall Guys. Overall, the game is still a lot of fun and I do at least still enjoy the experience I get by playing all the unique games offered overall. It just definitely seems that Epic has become a little bit of an over-controller by making the game feel somewhat like Fortnite. Especially with the currencies and store items. I do not in anyway blame Mediatonic for those changes. I'm sure that the only reason why they wanted to work with Epic is so that players could get custom usernames again. Which is nice since it felt weird being known as "Fall Guys 3927" or something like that. And even having a more unique generated name like Super Bouncy Bean something like that felt better but not the same. But once Epic knew they could have even more power, they really reshaped the in game currencies and store into something they're more comfortable with. I'm sure Mediatonic was a little skeptical when seeing if they wanted this change but I suppose Epic went with it anyway. But I shouldn't allow in game currencies or stores to ruin my overall experience with the game. After all the main purpose of Fall Guys is to just play the games and earn rewards. Which is why I still recommend this game. It is still a fun game and I am definitely excited to see what the future of Fall Guys holds!

(Gripes) Game can be frustrating, 
A.) Too many people in the starting matches (and final match sometimes)
B.) Controls are incredibly unreliable (still), grabbing sometimes works and sometimes does not. People on console for some reason have an optimized connection and will occasionally run faster for no reason. (Confirmed by playing on console to verify)
C.) Too many team based games, the reason why people quit when this game first came out is because  games like fallball go on wayyyyy to long and playing a teamgame takes control out of the players hands.
D.) Games where you have to grab (anything) are absolutely the worst due to previously mentioned control inconsistency. Sometimes you grab and it processes, other times you grab something and it doesn't register. 
E.) Loading, just to get back to main menu when you finish a match literally takes over a minute. Why is this a feature? Just do a match recap in a popup window from the home screen or something? You're taking players out of the experience when they want to get back into your game. Weird design choice.

All that being said, this is a unique experience and hopefully they can improve the frustrating annoyances because there is alot going on for this game. Its in an incredibly niche spot despite being a battle royale.

Try it yourself and see what you think.

A multiplayer competitive party game of races, obstacle courses, and other minigames to crown one winner from a the 60 beans that enter. Very cute. Very fun. Really nice to see the Battle Royale model applied to something besides FPS games.

Fall Guys: Ultimate Knockout may be adorable, silly, and simple to learn, but that doesn't mean it's a low-stakes game. Despite the party game vibe, it's still a battle royale. For most of the match I'm content to goof around, take reckless chances, and stop to celebrate with emotes before crossing the finish line. Getting ragdolled or shoved out of contention usually just makes me laugh. But as the end of the final round approaches I'm suddenly taking things seriously as hell. I may be a bean wearing a frilly pink tutu, but I want to win.

The concept of Fall Guys will be familiar to those that have seen game shows such as Wipeout or Takeshi’s Castle. Guide your very own customized jelly bean avatar through up to five rounds of inflatable carnage and you’ll have a shot at taking home the crown. Each match is framed as an episode and lasts around 15 minutes at most, which further drives home that TV show feel. The controls are simple with running, jumping, diving, and grabbing as your only tools to navigate obstacle courses, avoid enemies, or cling on for dear life in more survival-centered events that threaten to plunge you into the slimy depths. If you do happen to get eliminated then you have the option to watch those remaining battle it out for the title while the musical equivalent of glycerin is poured into your ears.

Dwarves were a short race, as their name implied, standing from 4'3"–4'9" (1.3–1.45 meters) on average,with gold dwarves a bit shorter.[10] What dwarves lacked in height they made up for in bulk; they were, on average, about as heavy as humans. A dwarf could weigh anywhere from about 160–220 lbs (73–100 kg). Dwarven males were a bit taller and heavier than their female counterparts. Like humans, dwarves had a wide variety of skin, eye, and hair colors, typically pale among shield dwarves and deeply tanned or brown amongst gold dwarves. Hazel eyes were common throughout the race, with blue eyes more common amongst shield dwarves and brown or green eyes found amongst the gold dwarves.

Male dwarves were often bald and grew thick facial hair, which was sometimes used to display social status. Unusually for humanoids, both sexes naturally grew ample facial hair, though the majority of shield dwarf females shaved their beards off. This hair was often dark in hue, though among shield dwarves blond or red hair was just as common. Gold dwarves took the care of facial hair to an extreme, carefully oiling and grooming it, with some adding perfume and ornamentations.

With the new Free-for-All update, the game has become super stale.

Unlike most Battle Royales, every level plays the exact same, so it can get repetitive really quick. The appeal for me, and I would assume most people, was the ability to get every single cosmetic (except 6 bundle skins) for free, just by playing. The idea of cosmetics that were locked behind wins was a really cool idea, but now, you need to pay for every skin and the battle pass. I think most people would rather pay $20 for the game and every skin, instead of $20 for a single skin that used to be free.

Now that it's F2P, I came back to try it out and the devs definitely upped their game since I last played. More unique minigames that have different mechanics to them. While I am very upset that my crown currency is now just normal kudos (just normal coins), there is the equivalent of V Bucks which I'm not happy about it but completely understand why it's there. While it's still more of the same, I think this is a nice casual (or tryhard if you want them crowns) time with friends. 7.0/10

This game is a bit of a mixed bag, and your enjoyment will largely come down to what you want out of a game like this. The core concept of the game is solid, but the execution feels off somehow. The few games I played made me feel as though I should be having tons of fun, but it felt like playing a Mario Party mini-game without the rest of the game to back it up. After the first few matches it began to feel very repetitive. I can completely understand why some people might enjoy this, but to me it felt like a good concept that got the core skeleton working but stopped before it could add any meat to the bones. 

Perhaps I will return to this game in the future, if more depth is added to the overall experience, but for the time being it felt too small in scope to be worth the money.

Having played this game at launch, I was entirely against coming back to this game. There were so many issues with the game when it debuted, like not having custom games, no 'crown shard' system, no dedicated squad/party modes, having a pretty irritating map pool and having servers that were as sturdy as a jenga tower on a shaky washing machine during an earthquake.

Having just gotten back into it through a friend and having completed this seasons battlepass, I can say that this is one of the best turnarounds I've ever seen from a game. Every issue I had at launch has been fixed, and I have thoroughly enjoyed playing this game again with my friends. It's the perfect game for coming home and just booting up for a bunch of mayhem and chaos lol.

Fall Guys is fun and family friendly.  The music is awesome and the art is colorful and cute.  Currently it is an online multiplayer only game so there is that to consider, but if you have a few friends you can play custom shows with just friends.  The game features a lot of short fun mini-games that have varying degrees of skill required to do well in them, that you play as a bunch of strange little jelly beans with arms and legs.

I'd say the game is easy to play but hard to master, with its minimal controls but learning curve of memorizing the layout and rules of the levels, and the skill checks on the harder rounds and finales.  For some users it could take several games to ever get a win (or even qualify the first few rounds) and for others it could happen in just a game or two.

Fall Guys currently features cross-play AND now also features cross-party, so you can squad up and play with your friends on any platform the game is on,  There are constant content updates and seasonal updates with unique shows, rounds, costumes and more to keep you playing in small bursts daily or weekly.

I would definitely recommend this game to people who like platformers, party games, and more casual multiplayer titles.  10/10 Love this silly Bean game.

I pre-ordered Fall Guys, and had an incredibly fun time in S1 running around as one of my favourite characters, the infamous Gordon Freeman.  As I cycle through games in order to maintain my evergrowing backlog, after I completed the achievements I put Fall Guys to one side hoping to come back to it at a later date. 

Fast forward a year from the last time I played it, I am now greeted with the need to use an Epic Account, agree to their EULA and linking their client to my Steam client. This is a concrete "No" from me, and I am appalled to see these practices implemented. I can only echo what I've seen from many other reviews here - using an Epic Account should be optional, not mandatory. I am a private user that cares about my data and where it is used, stored or goes.

Fall Guys: Ultimate Knockout is a multiplayer party game where you compete against 59 other people and try to beat sets of minigames only to be thrown into a finale and win it all. 

You can jump, dive or grab other people to mess with them or ensure your survival.

Minigames range from races, team games, survival rounds, scoring points to qualify.

The game works in seasons, each season the game gets a new theme, new maps and costumes/cosmetics. As you play you earn money that can be spend on cosmetics or emotes in the shop and you also earn experience which fills up your season pass which rewards you with something each level all the way to 50.

Months after release, the game recieved Squads ( que up with 3/2 or just one other friend and compete against teams of others), events where you have to complete tasks to get sets of points for special cosmetics ( like Ratcher and Clank costumes ) and special game modes that where you play the same map over and over until you reach the finale and try to win.

The big issue I personally have with the game is the content loop and while I understand that demanding updates frequently is not realistic, the way this game does it just isnt for me anymore. The experience for me was like this:

1. New season comes out. Play it as much as possible because its gone in 14 days. ( new levels always have a timer and then they get added into all the gamemodes, they are not gone forever but you cant specifically que them just like you would at the start of a season, why is that the case I dont know, it doesnt make sense at all since seasons last months )

2. Get burned out because you played too much. ( might aswell no life first few days if the new season only game mode is leaving soon )

3. Take a break because you are not having fun.

4. Come back near the end of a season, grind again to finish the season pass for cosmetics, quit again because the grind makes you dislike the game.

5. Repeat step 1

During season 4 I told myself that I dont really like this loop im kinda stuck in but I figured since it has been a bit early to judge the game Ill just keep playing and hopefully the game gets better in the future.

I wish I knew why are the developers alergic to reworking past minigames to make them more random instead of "if I always go like this I never get hit" bs. Its a bad way to describe it so lets just say if your strategy works once it will always work but it really shouldnt.

I also dont get why the season pass is only up to level 50. Once you reach it, there is nothing else to get, no extra levels that reward other ingame currencies, nothing. 

And finally the shop size stays the same despite adding tons and tons of new cosmetics every season, lets keep the shop nice and small to force players to check every day just incase there is something they want. Its stupid, the size should have been increased months ago.

And here we are over a year later and the game still does the same things over and over again and I cant lie to myself anymore and pretend that things will get better in the future. They cleary wont and its a damn shame.

Fortnite and PlayerUnknown’s Battlegrounds may have popularised the last player standing format, but Fall Guys: Ultimate Knockout has truly unlocked its potential by painting it hot pink and putting it in a hot dog costume. Mediatonic’s family-friendly formula is a colourful, bouncy breath of fresh air that takes a different, less explosive approach to battle royales without losing any of the tension. Instead of C4, it’s Vitamin C you’ll be steering clear of as you’re bombarded with monstrously overgrown oranges in just one of its two dozen game show-like events. The vast majority of these minigames hit the mark, offering fun and frustration in equal amounts. Couple them with a vibrant aesthetic and a brain-tunneling soundtrack and Fall Guys manages to make you want to punch the air when you’re winning and scream at your screen when you’re losing, but you’ll be laughing either way.
The concept of Fall Guys will be familiar to those that have seen game shows such as Wipeout or Takeshi’s Castle. Guide your very own customized jelly bean avatar through up to five rounds of inflatable carnage and you’ll have a shot at taking home the crown. Each match is framed as an episode and lasts around 15 minutes at most, which further drives home that TV show feel. The controls are simple with running, jumping, diving, and grabbing as your only tools to navigate obstacle courses, avoid enemies, or cling on for dear life in more survival-centered events that threaten to plunge you into the slimy depths. If you do happen to get eliminated then you have the option to watch those remaining battle it out for the title while the musical equivalent of glycerin is poured into your ears.

A game show is only as good as its games though, and this is where Fall Guys’ current pool of 24 largely triumphs. The obstacle course-style races are where I’ve found the most enjoyment, especially as it gets down to the wire as beans bounce off one another and desperately lunge for the finish line trying to make the cut.

I’ve been particularly enjoying the havoc of Hit Parade and the precarious spinning platforms of The Whirlygig, which often descend into chaos as twenty too many characters try to fit through a small gaps or all jump for the same narrow platform. There’s always more than one path to take, some offering a high risk-reward option, which is welcome as it never feels like you’re completely out of a race despite being near the back of the pack. In Door Dash you hurtle towards the bottom of a track attempting to dive through doors, some of which will blast open, whereas others will stay firmly shut. There’s a simple pleasure found in walking through an opening as the opponent next to you slams face first into a brick wall.

千小时正式退坑啦！从第一赛季开服玩到第6赛季，感谢糖豆人陪伴了我这么长时间。有过很有爱的互动，也认识了很多有趣的小伙伴，甚至还意外地参加了S3挑战赛，真的是很丰满的游戏体验了。
退坑原因大概主要是因为年纪大了血压承受不住哈哈，老倒霉体质加上我的老年笔记本本也逐渐承受不住越来越大的游戏体量，空闲时间玩几把要么莫名被闸要么卡顿掉线要么团队笨笨队友，要么自己手滑失足，血压飙升哈哈。很遗憾像我这种又菜又爱浪的玩家已经不适合它现在的游戏环境了。
不过如果有小伙伴一起玩，糖豆人现在的可玩性还是很高的。游戏内容和技巧越来越多，模式逐渐丰富，一些经典地图也百玩不腻。
虽然糖豆人在玩家角度看来确实存在过一些很离谱的运营问题，但不得不说这是一个现象级的好游戏。希望它能有更长久的生命力。退坑留爪，再见，祝好！

This game is adorably fun. 

It's a battle royale game that still has a solid tree of unlockables and entertainment. The rounds are challenging, unique and random so you never know what you'll get in each show. 

I play more on my ps5 these days but there is still some issues with hackers that need to be addressed. Other than that the game is a lot of fun with friends, I wish you could party up with more than just a few people but still provides a lot of fun regardless. 

Some of the cosmetics are a bit too pricy, it's good that you can unlock some of the items through just playing the game, such as the 2B outfit or some of the older exclusives. I don't play this game nearly enough to sink money into it but can definitely see why people do for the cosmetic upgrades!

All in all a fun game to play every once and a while with a few friends.

I actually loved this game and have had it since release. Unfortunately the Fall Guys team felt it was necessary to permanently ban my account for "software that affects the game..."

This was just a wrong and false accusation on their part. I have never once cheated nor did i plan to. If I were cheating, I think i'd have WAY more crowns under my belt lol.

I wasn't too mad at first, as I thought the support team would unban my account once realizing the mistake. It has been over a week and I have put 3 support requests in, tried reaching out on the Fall Guys discord, and even went to FallGuys social media pages. I have gotten ZERO help and no replies from FallGuys support, even though they state replies should happen within 72 hours.

Although I love the game, it's hard to recommend a game to others when there's a chance they'll ban you and pocket the money you spent on it. I have found others online with the same problem as me, but hopefully it's not too common.
Finally, a Battle Royale that's actually not super sweaty and fun to play.

If you want to get into this game, I recommend looking into some of these features within the game before making your judgement. This post will be a cumulative list of the worst of Fall Guys, and will go on for a while, so be warned.

Going into this list, I want you to keep two key facts in mind. Number one, take into consideration this quote, in its absolution, no edits, no paraphrasing, from the March 2nd, 2021 official Mediatonic release about their acquisition by Epic Games:

[quote=Mediatonic]"Joining forces with Epic will accelerate our plans to improve the game and bring Fall Guys to as many players as possible, while continuing to support the community."[/quote]

Second, consider the fact that most, if not all, of the clips I will be sharing were delivered [b]on level release[/b]. Some of these features date back to the game's early months. I want you to consider this: an error in the game that lasts a couple of weeks is a bug, a hitch in the experience. If that issue persists into month durations, that's no longer a bug. That's the experience the developers want you to be having while playing this game.

These are the types of experiences that the developers have left unchecked for several months, and thus, want you to be experiencing by buying this game.

(Big thanks to YT channel Top Fall Guys Highlights for compiling these. All of the clips below are within the game as of Season 6 and to this day can still be replicated. Some of these have been [strike]bugs[/strike] features in the game for more than a year+)

There are clear takeaways I'm obviously noting from the quote from before. Improving the game, and supporting the community. Allowing players to experience the true, undeterred Fall Guys experience that Mediatonic wants you to experience when you play the game. 

I ask you, though. Surely if these were to be considered bugs and glitches, then Mediatonic would absolutely take time to remedy these issues, and if these were issues to begin with, then keeping them within the game for several months and counting means that the community is [i]wrong[/i], and these are indeed the improvements promised to us with the newly acquired resources necessary to bring the game to its best potential.

All of the links I provided aren't just occasional [strike]bugs[/strike] features that have blipped in and out throughout Fall Guys' lifespan. These have and have always appeared consistently and throughout the game's whole entire lifespan, and have never once been taken out of the game. At best, these can be considered controversial additions to gameplay, and at worst, these are haphazard displays of lack of support and a disconnect from the community to sustain the game properly. 

I absolutely adore this game, and have grudged through its tenure in my library balancing the good and the bad. I've been through its original fad status, the lack of updates and disappointing Season 2, the savior of Squads mode reincarnating the game, the custom playlist cycles, and have been a day 1 player in each and every new season. After hundreds of hours, I can definitely mark my feelings down in this review. This is a good game with a horrible company, not malicious or evil, but absurdly lazy to the point that the most dedicated players aren't here just cause they're good - it's that these above experiences are so integrated into daily gameplay that at this point we just don't care anymore.

My negative review is unrelated to the epic games thingy, it's mildly annoying and I wish it was optionnal, but ultimatly I don't care and Fall Guy isn't the first or last game to require third party authentification, at least it's not a single player game.
No, my problem with fall gay is the lackluster level design and annoying character physic. 
Level Design  : 1) Some levels are purely random, 2) some are just not well suited to large crowd of playable character that can bump into each other, 3) some are team based chalenge but the game is supposed to mostly be free for all, meaning these put you are the mercy of your unchosen teamates skills, 4) finaly, couple of levels require way too finicky and precise mouvement considering the physic engine.
No need to elaborate about the annoying character physic, it's pretty much self explanatory. And I couldn't find a way too easily pratice level, and it's just unimmaginable for me to have a racing or scroring base game that one can't practice in solo before or in between multyplayer sessions.
Now, Fall Guy isn't too bad  of a game, it can be fun but you either have to take it lightly that  goofing around with friends is your only goal or competively and accept to getting used to the weird physic.
If wholesome was a game this would be it.

I got this game for the only main reason to play with others, but ended up playing it by myself. I actually thought it would be very easy but actually is harder than you think. I do not get tilted easily but this game gets me going, maybe because I do not know how to play good. When it comes to how long the gameplay is, it does really depend on you but also others, the overall matches aren't very long. You would definitely could squeeze in one game before work or school. Not that I encourage people to try to and risk getting late. But you could. Otherwise, hard to admit, but through my tilt, I did enjoy it and It is worth the price too! Even though I probably would have waited for the sale if I didn't have anyone who wanted to play it with me. 

I hope you found this review somewhat helpful or enjoyable! Please also leave a rating and give me your feedback and ideas in the comments. I would love to read your thoughts, ideas or/and your own experiences of playing this game!

Are you bored? Need something mindless but fun to preoccupy your time? This is it, a simple premise, fair controls, a touch of skill, and the opportunity for some mario kart style cheese (except instead of blue shells you'll get tilted by weirdos trying to grab you).

The game is entertaining (esp when co-op w/ family & friends), queue times are minimal, plenty of unique maps and game modes, adding new ones each season, and overall a solid game.

Only downside is the Epic anti-cheat solution, sometimes has a false alarm with other software if opened between/during games.

This game was and continues to be an extremely innovative and refreshing battle royale. I may have jumped on the train late due to not having a platform to run it for a while, but it's still a boatload of fun. The battle royale genre is oversaturated with shooters, and while they aren't inherently a bad thing, they start to get old. Fall Guys takes the genre into a completely new direction, rather than bandwagoning, and it does it very well. You compete in a variety of minigames, trying to qualify for the next round until the last. On top of the diversity of the minigames, there's also smaller variations to spice things up. And the best part is, you can actually interact with players, grabbing, shoving, bumping, affecting the environment for other players, and such are all possible, which adds on to the replay value because it doesn't just feel like a chaos mode single player game like Nintendo's battle royales, which also tried to break trends but did it poorly imo. On top of this core gameplay, there's also other modes like squads & events to further spice up gameplay, and new cosmetics and new minigames from time to time to flesh out the content. Devs also seem pretty great too.

Tl;dr Tired of shooter battle royales, or less effective non-shooter ones? Give this game a try, it's very fun, creative, and well made!

Let's just start with I'm a console player and have been since I can remember (OG NES days) I recently bought a Gaming rig as I wanted to edit videos and play games that were available only on PC... The bright colors and craziness of it all makes this ADHD brain happy.

The music is energetic and chaotic in a very well blended way.
The levels are not dull with the mechanics implemented.

Definitely a game that will humble you in the sense that you cant ALWAYS be a God (Kinda like FPS BR's)

The graphics are amazing. When you get in game that is when you appreciate how well "great graphics" and "childish graphics" have been mixed together. The gameplay is as if you are a child again and you are watch "Takeshi's Castle" while giving it some childish imagination. The audio is satisfying and the music keeps you in a good mood. There is a misunderstanding that this game is reserved for kids but any age group can enjoy this. If you think it is bad because it is dead, you will be wrong. Those mistakes have been corrected and the game is slowly coming back to life. Don't play this game if you have a tablet pc that microsoft sells. I am telling you this because back then that was my only windows computer. But if you have a laptop you are fine. You shouldn't use a trackpad for this though. Keyboard and mouse is fine but I like to use a controller. It is easy to learn but hard to master since players have gotten insanely good. It is not necessary to grind unless you want skins. As of now the story is not within the game it is in the trailers. But there is a rumor that this year in april there will be an event like fortnite and there are files to prove it. The game time is an odd question I get asked and it is online so the time can go to infinity and beyond! There definetly are bugs but they are bugs to have fun with and not glithy and frustrating. You should buy if it is on sale, but if you are a normal gamer and not like me then it is worth the prize. I am a casual so I got it when steam told me there were 2 different sales on it so I said why not? Overall 9/10.

Pala
Una pala es una herramienta de mano utilizada para excavar o mover materiales con cohesión relativamente pequeña. Consta, básicamente, de una lámina con una ligera curvatura y de un mango con el que se maneja. La tabla o plancha suele ser metálica y el mango remata generalmente en un asidero que puede ser recto o curvo, para poder ejercer mayor fuerza con una de las manos.1​ La pala se ha empleado desde la más remota antigüedad en labores agrícolas y de construcción.

Su evolución ha dado lugar a las máquinas excavadoras y cargadoras, muy importantes en las tareas de movimiento de tierras para remodelación y acondicionamiento de terrenos, construcción de infraestructuras urbanas, conformación de sótanos, preparación de cimentaciones de edificios, etc. En países como Perú a la pala la llaman lampa.


Características
La pala es un instrumento conformado por dos partes: una plancha de madera o metal y un mango cilíndrico.2​ El tamaño de la plancha y el grosor y largo del mango dependen del uso para el cual la herramienta está destinada.3​

El mango posee una empuñadura para facilitar el agarre. Existen tres tipos de mango según su empuñadura:

Mango anilla (tipo D)
Mango muleta (tipo T)
Mango largo (todo uniforme)
Y, según el tipo de trabajo para el que una pala está destinada, existen 3 tipos de planchas:

Con punta redonda: utilizadas para trabajos en los que haya que excavar, ya que la estructura redondeada terminando en punta hace que sea más fácil hincarla en la tierra.
Cuadradas: utilizadas para trasvasar o recoger materiales, escombros, cemento, tierra, etc.
Palote, también llamado pala plana o pala de zapa: tiene la punta cuadrada pero toda la superficie es más estrecha y plana. Utilizado principalmente en jardinería para trasplantar, recortar o perfilar el terreno.
Materiales
El material de fabricación del mango puede ser de madera u otros materiales como fibra de carbono. Las palas con mango de madera son más económicas pero menos resistentes mientras que las palas con mango de fibra son más caras pero más resistentes.

Las palas más utilizadas son las construidas de acero especial, el cual tiene una gran resistencia. No obstante, también hay modelos de aluminio y de plástico. Estas últimas son utilizadas en actividades que no permiten el uso de acero o bien donde el material a tratar dañaría el acero. Este es el caso de palas para la nieve, trabajos en alimentación, combustibles, etc.

La ventaja de las palas de aluminio permite una mayor facilidad de movimientos.

Tipos
Según la forma y material de la placa rígida del extremo y de las características del mango, las palas pueden clasificarse en varios tipos:4​

Palas para agricultura: las palas para el trabajo en la tierra cuentan con una placa con terminación redondeada y algo puntiaguda (como un filo) para favorecer la tarea de excavación. En algunos casos la parte inferior es plana para marcar surcos en la tierra y delimitar el espacio a excavar. La pieza metálica tiene un borde superior plano para ejercer fuerza hacia la parte inferior con el pie. El extremo de su mango puede ser en “T” con el objeto de empujar hacia abajo con la mano y el brazo, o también triangular. En todos los casos tanto el mango como su extremo son de madera cilíndrica.

Palas para jardinería: existen palas que se utilizan para el trabajo doméstico en el jardín. Su elemento metálico es estrecho y puntiagudo y su mango muy corto, como para ser empuñado con una sola mano. Estas palas son muy útiles para cavar pequeños huecos en la tierra en la tarea de introducir semillas o trasplantar flores, por ejemplo.


Pala de jardinería.
Palas para construcción: las palas para mover materiales de construcción tales como cemento, piedra, arena, suelen tener un mango más largo y una concavidad más pronunciada en la plancha inferior, tan ancha como para abarcar una mayor superficie. Esto facilita la tarea de cargar pequeñas cantidades de material y luego volcarlas sobre una carretilla o la caja de un camión para su transporte.

Palas para el aseo: son pequeñas palas, en general plásticas, que cuentan con el extremo cuadrado y perpendicular al mango. Sirven para recoger residuos, polvo y otros desperdicios que fueron previamente acumulados con el uso de un recogedor.

Palas para horno: se trata de palas con una plancha plana y ancha, así como un mango muy largo. Son herramientas indispensables para retirar alimentos de los grandes hornos sin correr riesgos de quemaduras. Generalmente son de madera, material que no transmite el calor.

Palas mecánicas: las palas mecánicas o cargadores representan la versión motorizada de este concepto de herramienta. Mediante el ensamble de un gran contenedor al frente de un tractor, se consigue el movimiento de grandes cantidades de material, tanto para tareas agrícolas como en la construcción.

Otros usos
Las palas de plástico forman parte de los juguetes que utilizan niñas y niños en la playa para manejar la arena. Forman parte de kits que incluyen utensilios tales como un cubo, un rastrillo o unos moldes. Las utilizan para cavar y transportar la arena, realizar riachuelos, construir castillos de arena, etc.

When I purchase a game I do so taking the risk whether it is bad or not, that I accept, but to bring in account linking and passing information to another separate service AFTER my purchase, thereby changing my aggreement, that's just plain wrong.

I'm downright terrible at this game. Normally, I'd stay far away from a game like this, not giving it a second thought as I skip it in my discovery queue. However, it's so cute and colorful that I'm willing to  overlook the fact that I'm so bad at it and watch the rounds following the one that eliminates me (usually the first one).

It makes me so happy that I can watch the subsequent rounds and choose a random jelly bean to root for. Do you have any idea how entertaining it is to wake up your neighbors at 4am by shouting things like "you go, Slurpee! Oh yeah, make that weird looking goose choke on your dust as you breeze past it! Get it, Slurpee!"? I didn't until just now, and it's as fun as you'd imagine.

Then after many of us already purchased the game, they of course disabled that option (after a few months) and were just too lazy to add it into the game themselves. 

And now they are forcing us with Epic Games account login. Again, months after we already purchased the game. These have to be one of the most shady and anti-consumer practises from a game developer that I've seen in a long time.

Each season brings a new variety of games to add to the culmination of all the games from previous seasons (currently on Season 6 as of writing this). 60 player lobbies, kid-friendly because there is no voice/text chat, and great for gamers of all levels. Each game takes no more than 15-20 minutes to complete and very quick to enter a new lobby if you don't qualify in a round. You can play with up to 3 other friends in your squad and take on the games either solo, or as a team (depending on the show that you choose). Also, you can host private lobbies with up other friends, however I would only recommend that if you had around 40 people to play with you.

There can be a couple of bugs here and there, however, Mediatonic has been pretty on top of it with patches and bug fixes. No cheaters after they implemented the easy anti-cheat (but that was after Season 2 or so). 

Overall, for the $20-$25 (forgot how much it was when I bought it), it is a great platforming battle-royale and I would recommend it for all ages!

I would have recommended this before, but as soon as Epic got their hands on it (and Mediatonic) and forced people to have an Epic account linked to it then I absolutely cannot. This type of thing should be illegal in gaming so far as I'm concerned, just like adding DRM post-release should be. Epic is a terrible company with anti-consumer practices and Sweeney is a clockwork hypocrite. Both this game and Mediatonic should not be supported because of this.

Finally, I'll leave this quote to illustrate that Epic and Sweeney don't practice what they preach.

July 21st 2020 -- "Ultimately, ownership of digital items should be a universal notion, independent of stores and platforms. So much of the digital world today is frustrated by powerful intermediaries whose toll booths obstruct open commerce to keep customers and their purchases locked in" -- Tim Sweeney via Twitter on EGS integration with GoG Galaxy 2.0

And that was mere days before they got their mitts on Rocket League and did pretty much the same thing (along with removing it from the Steam storefront). Again, forcing accounts, DRM or any other anti-consumer practices on a game post-release should be illegal.

I bounced off this when it first came out.  While I tried to get into it, the rounds were too luck-based and repetitive, and it just seemed impossible to get a crown.  Watching things I would've liked to buy enter and leave the shop repeatedly while I got slapped down due to bad luck got old fast.

Fortunately, that's no longer the case.  The maps from the first 2 seasons are notably worse than everything that has come in the next 4, which has created a much more varied experience.  The ability to play as squads helps when you can still be carried through even if you get knocked out due to bad luck.  The game also now gives crown pieces which turn into full crowns, so you can still slowly build up a good collection of them even if you aren't winning.  Along with some very fun crossovers, I can now really recommend the game as a solid multiplayer experience with a lot of ways to play.

Fall Guys is a test of basic timing and platforming with a good dash of luck thrown in. The stingy distribution prevents hyper-competitive mindsets from forming in the majority of players. With customization options that allow people to express themselves, I highly recommend this game for those wanting a casual time-waster. The only downside I can mention is the existence of cheaters who utilize hacks to win unjustly. This is a pitiful display but one found in many games on the market. 

If you want a vibrant silly game where you're just as likely to win a crown as you are to get covered in slime then this is the game for you.

I use mouse/keyboard for probably 95% of the games I play. That being said, I use a controller for Fall Guys. Trust me on that, it makes the game 100% easier to play.

Most games I play off steam (like MMOs) make you have a separate account to play anyhow, so it's not a big deal that I have to connect my Epic account to play. Unistall and negative review.

This game saved my life.

I am 27.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ing minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you

Got boring and they stopped listening to their buyers. Grassroots esports tournaments for the game also died because Mediatonic did not listen to the community regarding fixing glitches and fixed extremely minor ones, including making a certain weekly mode unfun to finish because people stacked crowns easily (actually, this isn't actually a problem because there are other modes, the entire fact that it's a live-service and if the servers are gone, nobody can play is the issue).

Also, Mediatonic was bought by Epic Games, so don't buy [EDIT: play] this until it becomes free on the Epic Games Store.

(The only plus is that because of the Epic Games account syncing, you could just launch the game on your PS4/PS5 PSN linked to the Epic Games account and if you unlocked achievements on Steam already, you can automatically earn them instantly on PS4/PS5, so you don't have to redo the achievements on PSN. That's the only plus. Once syncing was available, it had been months since I already 100% the achievements on Steam. I launched the game on PS4 with the PSN account already linked to my Epic Games account (bought PS+ for a month since it was required to launch the game; stupid console multiplayer subscriptions), and autounlocked all the achievements that unlocked on Steam and got my first Platinum Trophy as a result. When it launches on Xbox One/Series S/X (they might skip Xbox One just to troll Xbox owners EDIT: They didn't skip Xbox One, thank God), the same thing will happen, just with Xbox Achievements. Most likely, the game will be F2P at that point when it launches on Xbox and Switch, which is why they delayed those launches. EDIT: That's exactly what happened.)

Nothing interesting has been happening though and esports for the game died after already rich and successful streamers on Twitch for Twitch Rivals were able to compete to get even more money and I didn't have a single chance to compete because I'm not a streamer even though I got the idea of the game fast, so that sucks. This was supposed to be my next esport after Sprint Vector and that chance already died out of the water.

LAST EDIT: It will now be free on EGS for Season 7. I called it. They have fucked over their OG buyers though because they are only getting a few costumes, a tag, and one premium season pass for Season 7 and then no more Premium Season Passes. I paid $40 for this for esports, couldn't compete, and got fucking ripped off.

Although the game has received a nice revamp, they now force you to use an Epic Account, agree to their EULA, handing over some extra data regarding you and/or your Steam account (via vinculation), and installing some extra software/services in order to use that account and probably fetch some extra data about you.

There literally was no need to, and reasons such as it avoiding exploits through usernames should not even be why. This addition is just as much of a nuisance as was owning a Microsoft account (to simplify it) to play games back in the days. It also forces players that do not trust the company due to legitimate reasons to hand over their data.

Using an Epic account should be optional, and not something mandatory.

This game has technical issues:

Wide screen resolutions aren't support
Higher refresh rates than 60 aren't supported. Sure you can select 144+ but every character other than yours will be a blurry mess

Team mode is terrible. If it does not fill to the full 60/60 players you can have a 3 person team and are guaranteed to lose

Most games are pure RNG and there's not much strategy/skill to the final rounds

If they improved the technical aspects this very cute game would be better but there's no excuse for a game in 2021 to not support modern hardware when even titles such as Warcraft III do
So i need an EPIC ACCOUNT for play a STEAM GAME? WT*!!!!! Uninstall and i want my refund! I HATE THIS ARROGANT EPIC GAMES!
This is my absolute favorite game right now, I'm completely addicted. I've played it for 1020 hours and 100% think it was the best purchase ever.

This game requires less skill than playing solitaire.
99.99999999% of the time you lose you have absolutely no fault.
You often die because some useless idiot with the wolf skin or the gingerbread man skin bodyblocks you (with the mass of an aircraft carrier loaded with tanks) making you fall.
Sometimes you fall because your character suddenly becomes invertebrate or has a violent fit of convulsions after landing on a platform. 
It often seems that the character has skates under his feet.
Sometimes you don't qualify for the next round simply because you have had the bad luck (or the lack of skill, according to many) to be spawned in the last row. 
Sometimes you fall from collisions that seem to be made by a drunk fool at a bachelor party.

Some games are simply badly designed. You have to escape by a slime that runs like Verstappen on the Abu Dhabi circuit while you get chain-bodyblocked by those clowns of the other players while you have to dodge the worst obstacles with potato collisions.

This game is vaguely fun when played as a team without even trying to commit.

I mean, if you think you like the graphic style and the variety of character skins (there are many collaborations and 
the game gets updated) and you are intrigued by the idea of ​​playing a Takeshi Castle game that requires more luck than flipping a coin, buy it.
Otherwise, save your money.

Fall Guys is plain and simple can be a good time or bad time. Win or losing its all about being number one by yourself or with friends squading up. It's been bugging me that hardworking developers, artists, designers, marketers, and everyone in between- all of whom are clearly passionate about their work- are being dragged through the mud for a decision that in all likelihood never fully rested upon their shoulders.

I understand that the Epic Games store and its reputation is subpar, to say the least. Everyone here knows the bad and the good about them. I'm not here to condone and/or support any of their practices.

But I am here to give my unpopular opinion that Mediatonic's poor choice to use Epic Games as a medium for creating accounts has quite honestly brought a lot of good with it. Crossplay existed before, but what will soon be possible is the ability to add people from all platforms as friends, which was supposed to be the main selling point of the move. We now have an easy way to implement usernames on PC, because when the game first came out we abused the game's structure to create names that could crash other people's PCs. Runtimes and loading times are better, and hackers are just about nonexistent at this point... all of this is just based on what I've personally noticed.

What I'm trying to say is that this is just a well-developed, silly little game to play in short bursts. If you want to support the creators, but want nothing to do with Epic, you can always make a burner account to enjoy the same old game it's always been. Please don't judge the game too hard just based on their new development alone. I think Fall Guys is good for what it is, and deserves a lot more love than that.

I'm probably going to regret leaving comments on but I actually value feedback so here we go.

I bought this game because I wanted it.
I wanted to play the game.
That's it. 

It's 2021 currently and most services require you to sign in or sign up.
I consider myself to be a power user and I frequently use as many functionalities as I can.
That being said; I have an account for pretty much every platform I use.

Hot take warning!

Giving a company your email and password is literally the lowest possible effort thing you can do.
In exchange you get to use the service.
That's a privilege, not a right.

What ever a company's reason for requiring you to SSO or create a new account is often clearly stated.
and it seems very clear to me (a user who agrees to the terms of service) that my account is integral to the service.

Pragmatically, you have a few options.

You can say "Epic bad", refuse to elaborate further, and cease cooperation with the service. (Stop playing)
I promise it affects you less than it affects Fall Guys.

Or

You can link all your profiles, and never have to worry about change again.

I regularly choose the latter. 
because it's easier.

I read a comment that went something like this.

"I've not met one person who criticizes Epic's business model that is able to: 
Explain Epic's business model
or
explain to me how Steam's business model is any more consumer / developer friendly
The Epic-Bad-Give-Me-Steam-Awards reviews are pretty exhausting to sift through."

I agree.

Now, keep in mind I don't have a preference.
as a "power user" I use both platforms (Steam and Epic) all the time.
I think both leave much to be desired.
but I think most people (including myself I don't want to sound pompous) lack a really deep understanding of fullstack game development.

There are more moving parts than we will ever know, and as a simple player:
I don't think a single button press is too much to ask.

Very enjoyable (but sometimes infuriating!) battle royale game combining classic platformers and adding a competitive element to it. The game had been improved greatly in my opinion with the addition of squad mode so it isn't all just PvP but also some cooperative play too :). Only downsides to this game might be the very high skill cap of this game due to 'win grinding' by top players mixing in with new players, plus 'team' rounds in the single player modes. Adding competitive, as well as casual mode, will give new players much more chance of winning games and not being put off to a large degree. Keep up the good work Mediatonic! Game design really takes a lot longer than most realise and I respect the work you put into each and every update to balance player satisfaction and round/show quality.

I truly did love this game when it first came out. Was really excited for it when it was shown off in devolver digital's e3 video, bought it day 1. While it had a bit of a rocky start, I had fun playing the game. Talked some friends into getting it too, and while one of them never even won a single crown, for a time we had a blast playing it.

But then the hacker wave hit, player names were removed, and over time all my friends stopped playing the game. I guess I stopped playing too when they left. But still, the game had a spot in my heart, and I always intended on going back someday.

Then Epic bought the devs. I knew from that point on I never would return to the game. It was only a matter of time until Fallguys required an epic account, the same thing happened with rocket league back in the day. I truly despise epic at this point, every scummy business practice, every broken promise, almost every single action they take justifies my dislike of them. Unless you don't care about epic, or you for some reason actually like them, stay away. Don't waste your money on this game. It is and always will be infected by epic now.

I realized that some Epic Games Online Services was installed on my computer which I never installed nor was I given a warning that it will install. This practice of installing software on my PC without my consent is disgusting.

They should have given us a warning and ask for our permission to install such garbage on our computers, especially since this game originally worked just fine without it.

I uninstalled the service, game still works, but seriously, this should not be a thing. Steam, fix this, you are in charge of security and this by some can be considered a vulnerability; unknowingly installing programs on your clients PC.

EDIT:

So apparently with every launch of the game, this Epic Games Online Service keeps re-installing itself, therefore I just uninstalled the game. I can't be bothered anymore. Perhaps if they would have rolled this out friendlier, I would not have cared as much.

Well, I have to agree with the current sentiment - this is not a good move and not fair to all previous customers who had no chance to agree to this before buying the game.
The Epic Games account really should be optional and only necessary if you'd want crossplay at best and at worst optional for previous players and necessary only for future customers (if it's clearly mentioned on the store page - which it now is).

At this point however I'd advice anyone who wants to play this game to maybe just wait a bit until it becomes free to play on Epic Store (which I don't have an issue with, if the game gets to the Epic Store it's obviously ok to have an Epic account there - but it should not be necessary for Steam users to even start the game).

I think it's bad when Ubisoft does it, I think it's bad when EA does it, I think it's bad when Microsoft/Xbox does it and I think it's bad when Epic does it.
