The hype train for Fall Guys took off as quickly as it came, but those who never left have been generously rewarded. With the support of current franchise owner Epic Games, the humble team at Mediatonic have continued listening to their loyal fandom and have consistently delivered fresh and fun new content, and overall improvements in gameplay.

They have delayed the development of the Switch and Xbox versions to improve on cross platform compatibility, and while it's still not perfect, the sixth season does offer one significant new feature: synchronized progression, thanks to integration with your Epic Games account. If like me you had sunk a lot of time into the PlayStation version, launched as the most downloaded free PS+ title of all time, this will provide incentive to buy the PC version and take all your saved up fame, crowns, kudos and costumes with you between platforms. Unfortunately you're still not able to create proper parties that are cross platform beyond custom lobbies, where progression cannot be achieved, but you'll finally have a good reason to play with your Steam friends.

The PC version could still benefit from more compatibility with older hardware and peripherals, lower resolutions and all that, but at the lowest settings it provides currently, most PCs that lag behind should at least get a playable framerate between 15 and 30 FPS.

If you've enjoyed any previous Fall Guys season before, season 6 brings you more or less the same experience as always. There are fun, new gimmicks on levels, but I'm hoping down the line there will be different kinds of levels beyond races, team challenges and whatever else they got now. They've been teasing a new game mode coming in the near future called "Invisibeans", but what that'll be like remains to be seen.

Overall, Fall Guys remains a bastion of gameplay that is cute, quirky, competitive, and fun for all ages, and still just as much fun to play on your own or with friends. Perhaps even more fun on PC, where griefers are surprisingly less present than on PlayStation. With the inevitable Steam winter sale on its way, you might want to pick this up. If you're a friend of mine and you haven't got it yet, I'd love to play with you!

Fix for cursor issue: When the game starts and the screen with "start" written on it appears, move your cursor to the top right quarter. Here a little white "X" will appear during loading after you have pressed any button to continue. Click this "X" , it will return you to the start menu abandoning the load. Some claim doing this once will fix, I repeated 3 times to be sure, but it did fix the issue.

I've pretty legitimately been on the fence about this review for some time, and in light of recent events, I figure I may as well cast my lot with the rest of the complaints. To make a long list of complaints short, Fall Guys suffers from Dead By Daylight Syndrome. Developers who consistently ask for feedback that is then consistently rejected, community management being unresponsive and generally not servicing their purpose - a link between the devs and community - and horrible feedback after an unfortunate publisher experience. Despite constant community feedback about events, both in game and on social media, shows, and account options, mediatonic and now Epic seem to refuse to learn from their errors voiced by a very loud majority.

Needing to now have an Epic account and app downloaded to play - especially after leading people to believe the change would be optional - is the straw that broke the camel's back.

Fall Guys is one of those breakout hits that fully deserves its success, not because it’s one of the greatest games ever made, but because it’s the perfect game for its time and place. In another year, I think this would have had its fans, but in 2020, during a global pandemic, in a time in which authoritarianism was on the rise and various Western nations were collapsing into political dysfunction, Fall Guys was a soothing balm. It’s a game that takes the framework of highly competitive online games and puts a goofy skin on it so charming that it’s hard to take it seriously. Instead of the often-toxic, murder-all-your-enemies games, Fall Guys is presented as a game show, in which strange bean people clumsily jump, grab and slide towards victory.

It makes such a lovely first impression that many people are inevitably disappointed that it gets repetitive. This is true; it’s a simple and accessible game, and that means that there isn’t enormous depth to its mechanics, which means to stay engaging it needs new content in the form of new levels amd modes, which takes time and money to create. But the developer is on it, pumping out new levels regularly, and the game is only $20 at full price.

I really hope that some day they allow user-created levels and game modes, but otherwise I got no complaints.

Up to 60 fall people a.k.a. idiots jump in to compete in a variety of zany obstacle courses and mini-games, dressed in the most ridiculous of costumes, and only one can potentially earn the crown, maybe, as illustrated by the hilarious victory sequences. Everything is meant to be unfair and random though some skills and understanding of the goals for each round can help. If you only care about winning, this will increase your blood pressure, which is not good because you want to be there when they start building magnetized roads for the automobiles of the future - sorry to disappoint you but flying cars is not going to be a thing. If you understand the rule of the game, that you just want to be in for some goofy time and earn points to unlock customization while not taking things seriously, this game is a blast!

Have to give this game a thumbs down. Bought it at full price to support an indie studio with a great idea right before they sold out to Epic. I was patient with Rocket League but after this newest season (season 6) I am tired of it. They are requiring an Epic account to play which is eerily similar to Rocket League and is most likely a prelude to them removing it from Steam altogether. I played season four to completion but ultimately the game is not worth it given the hassle of dealing with Epic. I just want to play video games and not have a thousand different accounts. To be honest, I would say just buy a copy of Mario Party if you're looking for your minigame fix. I'll probably still play this game from time to time but the initial excitement has faded as I have to wonder what bad business decision they'll make next. They sold it as a benefit, but honestly, who in their right mind would have a game downloaded on Steam and be like, "Hey, I really want to play this on my Epic account, I'm so glad there's crossplay". Not to mention Epic exclusive content for the game to pull the base away from Steam (where they found their success) and it's time to put my foot down. Real shame this is the gaming world we find ourselves in nowadays. I miss the days where I could be a Nintendo Fanboy and fight my friends for which console was better but now we have mega corporations throwing money around to cause chaos in what has been a relatively enjoyable purchasing market. All I can say is you don't see people getting mad at good old games or humble bundle.

It was a great game, I quite enjoyed it. Unique and challenging, made me rage quite a bit. But in a good way. 
But as the seasons progressed, I find that they focused hard on how to get even more out of this game, and I am not speaking quality of gameplay. There have been questionable updates, and they usually break a lot before things are sort of fixed, but not really.
There's a bug where audio cuts out in the seasaw level that's been an issue for a while, and isn't being fixed. When you play with friends and end up spectating, it used to automatically focus on one of your friends... no longer does that. Now you spend ages clicking through all the players each round to find your friend.

Crossplay is a great idea, but why does it have to be done over epic games? If I wanted to play fallguys over epic games, I would not have bought it on steam? Now you're forced to either create an account or link an existing account, and I don't quite want that cancer on my operating system, considering the kernel-level anti-cheat, and I ask myself... why does it have to be kernel level? why does it want to root itself so deep into my system, for so called "anti-cheat"? No thank you.
I would have liked there to be an option as to whether or not I need this silly cross-play, if it means having to link another gaming library to a game that worked without it just fine.

If none of that interests you then it's still a great game to play.
But otherwise it's just something that will go to shit more and more.

This is a great game. That said, I'll write my major complains:

- No crossover with Nintendo Switch, which was promised long time ago
- Game physics are broken (I know the game was intended to be chaotic, so the gameplay is not meant to be accurate or great at all, but I do think this game would be a lot better if the beans were not so soft and fragile. I like to think that if fall guys was a 3D Platformer Battle Royale, it would be a great game)
- Grab is so unfair and unpredictable (I know if there is a mechanic on the game, we should understand it and play considering it, but a lot of times I felt that this particular mechanic is broken)
- When you're laggy, you're disconnected. I don't understand why developers had this decision of disconnecting players when their internet occilates, but it happens with me (and in countries like Brasil, where the internet is poor, it can be very frustrating), and the worst of all is that you lose the progress you make
- Seasons offers too little and lasts too long. The game gets repetitive and some season changes doesn't feel like it changes the game enough.
- The rewards of playing are really poorly made. They kept the reward system since season 1, when the number of players and the hyper were way higher. Although, the skin prices and the number of coins/crowns that you own feels unfair. You have to play a lot and be the best to follow the skin shopping. The daily-mission helped, but I guess it's not enough.
- On the same line, I feel like the rewards are only for the "number 1's". It's really frustrating when you make a run that gives you number 2 or 3, but you are rewardad with less than half of what number 1 gets (and most of the time you played the same amount of time as this other player).

Well, I do want to say I like this game a lot, specially when I play with my buddies, but those critics I made makes me enjoy a lot less the game. I think I should had pointed those things and I hope the developers can make it better (I actually write those things every survey they make too).

The best thing about this game is its potential to be a good game, but it fails in every other regard as the dev team continue to add more game modes that no-one wants to play that are completely different to the base game elements of racing through an obstacle course.

I think every time-trial racing based game I have played has more features, more game-play focus and is more user-friendly than this one. You can't even queue the new game modes they add in my country as they rely on people to opt in to the special game modes and still require 40 players to start, which means the server will just time out repeatedly. There are many ways that these modes could be implemented that would work around these issues, but Mediatonic are either not aware or not competent enough to figure these things out over more than a year of full game release. Some new game modes do nothing but showcase how poor their server options are, like grab the tail. 

Then they go and lock season 6 behind an Epic Games account, likely a desperate bid to get more awareness for their parent company as the game dies out forever due to a complete failure to deliver any content that would maintain interest for the player base. This game is novel, but the developers don't have a clue on how to keep it that way, and the options for different shows are terrible.

I bought this game on Steam to play it on Steam. I don't like EPIC. Neither its platform, nor its philosophy as a company. That is why I have never been interested in having an account at EPIC. And I will never do one because I am not interested in them.

I centralize all my games on STEAM. (I hate the need that all companies want to impose on us to have to use a thousand different platforms on my computer in order to play their games.) And since I bought Fall Guys in November of last year 2021, I have played an average of 20-40 minutes daily.

I was looking forward to the premiere of the 6th season. But what was my surprise when I opened the game after the update and now asks me for an obligatory EPIC account to continue playing this game on Steam?

As I have read, (because I have not even been able to enter the main menu of the game by NOT having; nor wanting to have; an EPIC account), has the Randomw naming system also been changed???

I have played more than 203 hours in a single year. But I think that if Mediatonic doesn't think about FORCE people to create an EPIC account for continue playing, they are going to lose a significant player base on Steam.

I certainly do not plan to create an EPIC account in a very far future, because I do not sympathize with that company.

And if this Mediatonic move has been forced by EPIC itself because Fall Guys is their property, I feel very sorry for them.

Please don't force us (Steam users) to create accounts with other companys when we have been playing 5 seasons of the game without problems. (And the CROSSPLAY has worked very well in Season 4 without forcing us to have anything to do with EPIC.)

Please think about it...
Don't force us to leave Fall Guys because EPIC wants to force us to register with them to continue playing this game on Steam.

It was the first multiplayer game in years that has hooked me for so long, and it really has (as dramatic as it sounds) this decision in Season 6 break my heart.

And despite everything, I am not going to create an account with EPIC, with STEAM it is more than enough for me.

The changes with Season 6 absolutely ruined the experience for everyone within the steam community out of the inconvenience of being forced to create multiple accounts to access a game you either just or already paid for. not only is it a dumb solution to bring back the highly requested "player created names" (which could've been easily stolen and used by someone else and you have no means of requesting it back), it also adds in a bucketload of inconveniences such as longer load time to sign into not only this games own server, but also Epic's own account service and they are known to violate the PC users security and run background apps behind the users back to gain access to information they have nothing to do with...

This small change by all account IS gatekeeping in its most vile form and it single handedly fractured the community in such a way that it might next to impossible to fully recover from because of the scummy nature that Epic is known for, and until this "inconvenience" for anyone that doesn't own the game on both systems is removed and changed to something better that should've been the solution in the first place...

Hello, First of all, Congrats on keeping it together and not buying in to the hype. I'm certain that this game will go into a full Epic games transition just like what happened with Rocket League. If you don't know what that is, it basically means that the game will move to Epic Games as an exclusive FREE title filled with Epic micro-transactions and it will no longer be sold on steam. Now this is just a speculation but if you want this game on your steam library (I don't know why would you want that) then you might have a limited number of steam sales to pick it up, otherwise I suggest to wait for it be FREE?!? 


Anyway, I'm going to list all the things that tortured me when I was playing this game so that you can feel good, gloat and mock me for being a stupid POS that I am.


[h1] In Game Name Debacle [/h1]

It took the devs more than a year to fix the in game name issue. We've been using prisoner names (aka random numbers) and random strings (3 random words) to identify ourselves for a whole year. And to pat themselves in the back for doing such a good job fixing a year old problem, they are bundling the new and improve in game name feature with an epic games account. 

By the way, this "feature" was a frequently asked question and they knew that people wanted their name back. It goes so far that if you ask the devs about it on the proper discord channel, a mod will delete your question and inform you why they deleted it (coz it's FAQ dammit). And if you ask the same mods if they can share any news regarding this matter, the answer that they will give you is that they don't know.

They even included this "feature" in a survey so that you can vote for it to be added to the game around season 4. JUST TO BE EXTRA SURE THAT THERE IS INDEED AN ACTUAL DEMAND.


[h1] Lackluster Mini Game Updates [/h1]

The extra maps that they release each season is not enough to change the overall experience at all. You would still play the same old maps and maybe once in a blue moon, if you are lucky, you will get a chance to play on the new stages. This is a recurring feeling that I had every time that a new season is released.


[h1] Uninspired Mini Games [/h1]

Some mini games are downright terrible that if you remove them from the lineup, it would improve the overall experience. It seems to me that these maps exist for quantity purposes.


[h1] Wonky Physics [/h1]

Beans just like to fall on the ground for no apparent reason. It's tolerable now but back then it was horrendous.


[h1] Launch Day Server Issues [/h1]

IMO, they don't have the immunity of being a new indie company now so I'm gonna add this. In fact, it shouldn't been excusable back then anyway.


[h1] Devaluing skins [/h1]

If you are like me and you love rare cosmetics then you didn't lose a thing when you decided to skip this game and their free season passes. All models are repurposed anyway with a new color scheme or minor model adjustments to make it seem different. Case in point, the lvl 40 caveman skin from the season pass was later recolored and released as a cheap skin.


[h1] Downtime [/h1]

There's just to much downtime in this game. From waiting on queues to fill up to 60, finishing a map early and waiting for other players to finish (only to find out that the next game is a team game and you are screwed anyway), long loading times when transitioning to a new map and the unskippable victory screen when you lost a final round to a russian roulette aka Fall Mountain and whatever the jungle variant is.   


[h1] Closing Remarks [/h1]

This is a rant but I just can't fathom how forgiving people are to this game just because it is accessible and cute. They got away with so much mediocrity where other games would've been blasted for it. The silver lining for me is that this company sell out and they removed themselves from Devolver Digital's catalog. I'm just done with this game.

Season 6 edit 2
Apparently you don't only need an Epic account to play you ALSO need to install their launcher for it to work.
 After days of looking for help in the discord server and official support mail, they told me you need to:
1) Close Fall Guys and Steam
2) Uninstall Epic Online Services
Start>Add or remove programs>Search for Epic Online Services and Uninstall
3) Verify files in Steam (please do this again even if you have done it before) 
4) Try to Play the game

Chances are you don't have that program so a pre requisite to their solution is to install Epic's client first, then uninstall Epic Online Services and THEN install it from settings in Epic's client. Then you will open the game and be forced to log in at Epic and merge your account.

男生女生向前冲线上版。吃鸡类型与闯关类型的完美结合，可爱简单，但也硬核残酷。
简单易懂的操作搭配精妙丰富的关卡设计，唯一的影响因素是玩家的熟练度。没有属性，没有加成，跳、扑、拉是唯三的操作，如何运用好却是一个难题。成为冠军的唯一方法就是比别人更熟练。每一次选择、每一次动作都会决定成败。

A very charming and amusing spin on the battle royale genre. Taking inspiration from slapstick game shows, you'll need to outrun, outmaneuver, and outlast a lobby of up to 60 players in order to achieve victory and claim the crown.

There are six categories of gameplay rounds. "Race" sends you stumbling through a gauntlet of obstacles to cross the finish line. "Survive" puts everyone on a platform over a pit of slime, where falling means elimination. "Logic" requires you to play a quick memory game to find the safe platforms. "Hunt" has everyone competing to rack up points in order to advance. "Team" divides the players into 2-4 teams, where the losing team is kicked out. And of course, "Final" is an intense showdown where only the best of the best (and luckiest of the lucky) can come out on top.

While you can play solo, there's also a "squads" mode where everyone plays with up to 3 friends (or random strangers). Success or defeat depends on the entire squad's performance, meaning that your squadmates can help you advance even if you falter, or that one poor player can cost their squad the game. No matter your skill level, luck is a big factor in determining whether you win a crown, and that's assuming you aren't pushed into the slime by dirty players.

The game's biggest highlight is its cutesy aesthetic, which includes the multi-color bean characters. There's just something so charming about the way they move and let out little "woo"s and "oof"s as they stumble and fall. Plus, they're highly customizable: everything from their color, skin pattern, costume, namecard, and even victory animation can be changed to your liking. Customization options are acquired either through the seasonal battle pass, in-game events, or the store. Sadly, many items are very expensive, making it hard to earn enough to buy them without resorting to microtransactions.

Despite the downsides, each major update every few months adds new themed levels and customization options, so there's always more to come back to. And I, for one, could always use more Fall Guys.

[h1]Ain't Falling for This BR! [spoiler]Fell for it hundreds of times[/spoiler] [/h1]
This might be the best Battle Royale game on the Steam eventhough it's not technically a BR! It has;
[list]
[*]60 players (ninja warrior-like!?) competition in a beautifully made platforms,
[*]Squad Play (Up to 4),
[*]New seasons & challanges to keep it fresh,
[*]Cross-play (playing same game with PC & console players),
[*]Decent jammer soundtrack,
[*]Variety of cosmetics
[*]Decent netcode & controller support
[*]All the sweet (and sometimes tilting) moments.
[/list]
Although this game is (one time) Pay2Play, it is a lot cheaper compare to a F2P game these days. (These fools don't even ask any dime for things like season pass >.<) If you are into this kind of games (human fall flat is the only game comes to my mind) I highly recommend this one. You can chill with it after a tough day or get even more tilted after falling to a random  grabber.
As final words I wanna mention few missing parts;
-It has no tutorial (so you have to discover levels & obstacles yourself.),
-no rank system or leaderboard (so you can play with all newbs in your squad) ((Although it doesn't really matter since you should play this to chill anyways))
-no option to filter your cosmetics and no indication to new ones.

[b]P.S. with season 6 update you have to connect with an Epic account[/b](hope they fix / revert it asap)

Update: As of the Season 6 Update in December 1 2021, Fall Guys now requires an Epic Games account to play. Without any notice in their Steam Store Page, and I heard that it'll make you install Epic Games application if you make an account through Fall Guys. We never got a say in this, and they'll be hearing from us on their next survey if they don't accommodate the Steam players who have bought the game over a year ago, before Epic Games took over. Epic Games shouldn't be the only way for crossplatform play and custom names.

Original Review (Recommended, 11-26-2021):
This game is underrated to this day. It still gets updated with new content and mechanics. Cute characters and fun minigames. I especially appreciate the new Squad Show modes (Squads and Squads Duos) since you don't get eliminated right away when you finish late or fall off in a survival game.

This game deserves the "Labor of Love" Steam Award 2021.

Fall Guys is enjoyable game for casual play; the premise of a minigame battle royale is a truly great one, and Fall Guys executes this well with surprisingly tight controls and a slew of incredible minigames to take full advantage of this gameplay style. 

[u][b]Unfortunately developers added mandatory Epic games account. So I can´t recommended this for playing on Steam.[/b][/u]

However, the base roster of minigames is somewhat sparse, and several of them don't reach the same highs as the ones mentioned above, with many of the team minigames and Picture Perfect feeling antithetical to the game's appeal. Still, the majority of the minigames are solid, and even the worst of Fall Guys' games can provide enjoyment and fun memories. As long as Fall Guys' dedicated developers continue to release other strong minigames, this game is sure to keep some staying power and become more than the "flavor of the month" some claim it to be, and I look forward to seeing how they do.

My toddler daughter is at the age where she likes to watch me play games but isn't that interested in playing them herself yet.  I got this game for that reason.

PROS:

- The game is colorful and the levels are creative.
- My daughter enjoys watching it.
- There are some fun moments where you yell out loud during close calls and tight finishes.

CONS:

- No split screen.  It seems strange that a party themed game doesn't have local multiplayer support.  It would be fun to play this locally with my daughter but the game doesn't even support it.
- Too many veteran opponents to make this game fun.  It's built to have the appeal of a casual game(like Among Us) but the game has been around for a few seasons at this point.  The competition is now too stiff for casuals or new players to really get into it(for the record I consider myself a seasoned gamer).  I've been playing this game for roughly 6 hours total and have not won a single competition.  Heck, I haven't even finished first in a single round.  And I've never made it to the final round in any competition.  The game needs some kind of ranking system so that new players aren't immediately thrust into the grinder with opponents who already have multiple seasons under their belt.  Maybe the fact that you need 60 people to play a game limits the ability to implement a ranking system.
- Lot's of focus on DLC and paying for skins when the game already costs $20.  I acknowledge that DLC and paying for skins is a successful business model for keeping development teams afloat.  So this is just a minor gripe.  Developers gotta eat.  I get it.  The game isn't a pay to win model so there's that at least.  But its inclusion usually(but not always) indicates in a game that there's an emphasis on securing revenue over making a quality game.
- Since the game requires a large number of players to start, sometimes the game just isn't playable.  There are times where you are just waiting in the lobby for enough players to be online in order to start a game.  I wish there was at least a practice mode.

OVERALL:

I don't recommend the game.  It seems kinda gimmicky unfortunately.  Its fun for a few times but gets repetitive quickly.  You'll get tired of playing this before you get good enough to win.  There's enough hard core players of this game out there to make certain of that.

UPDATE(about a month after my original review):  When the new season started, it now appears that I ALSO need an EPIC Games account to continue playing Fall Guys.  Not necessarily against this if it were a game I wanted to continue to play, but it is annoyingly redundant to need to sign in to both Steam AND Epic Games to play a game.  This little nudge was enough to make me just pull the trigger and uninstall Fall Guys.

I really enjoyed playing Fall Guys despite its many flaws and shortcomings (slow content updates, bugs, no custom nicknames, problems with cheaters to name a few). It has a solid artstyle which conveys the overall goofiness and cuteness of beans. I just love it how Fall Guys is open to everyone, available for both casual players who want to simply have fun and more competitive players who try to learn new tricks and simply get crowns. There's something about Fall Guys that makes you laugh after you get eliminated and I really like it how I don't need to stress over elimination. The rounds are quick and you can always quickly start a new match.

Unfortunately, Season 6 will require an Epic account to play. As much as I'd like to play the new maps and unlock new costumes, I don't want to support Epic and their launcher. I don't want to create and use another account when I purchased the game on Steam and just for Steam. I don't want to have something imposed on me, against my wishes. Unless Mediatronic reverse this decision, this is the end of playing Fall Guys for me.

Having originally bought this game when it first came out, I decided to give Fall Guys another go after it went free to play since I would get the first post-F2P season's premium battle pass for free. While I am glad that there were significant improvements to matchmaking (especially with having different types of shows for playing solo, with a second player, or with three other players) and plenty of additional maps added to add more variety to each show, what ultimately kills the game for me is the F2P business model being a huge slap in the face to everyone that bought Fall Guys before going free to play. 

Simply put, Kudos are borderline useless for what you can use them on in the Item Shop, any Crowns that players earned before the transition to F2P only gives players more Kudos, Crowns earned now will increase your Crown Rank, which that in of itself becomes a chore with how many you would have to earn if you want reach the max rank and unlock everything, and everything else that you could originally exchange Crowns for? You now have to purchase the game's new premium currency, Show-Bucks, to buy the more desirable items, but with how pricey these items can be, it's not worth it unless you have some money to burn. Combine all of this with how you little Fame (XP) you get just from playing outside of daily and weekly challenges, and you have officially lost me altogether as a player. Sorry, Fall Guys, but after reaching Level 40 for the season and getting the Level 40 achievement, I'm done with you for good.

Something which most game developers seem to neglect is the fact that adding an item pass to a game with a list of collectables as the player meticulously grinds to get cosmetics that do absolutely nothing, is not what people want and is just seen as a way to desperately add new content each season to try and distract the player-base from the fact that no new major updates are happening, and yet the game company can still capitalise on the younger demographic of the game. This doesn't just apply to Fall Guys, but most other games that have these 'battle passes'. I find it completely ridiculous and just another way to milk money for themselves so they don't have to do as much work on the actual game. While still understanding that the game is not meant to be taken too seriously, it's also important to remember that a game like this one only has so much replayability value. Therefore, I'd like to say that while Fall Guys does a great job in the field of design and performance optimisation, the very nature of the game prevents you from enjoying it once you play it enough. I understand that this may be the case with almost all games, however fall guys has a shorter lifespan in the eyes of the player, which is why it's dying, in the way that among us is. Upon buying the game I had an enjoyable experience however that experience was only present when playing with friends.

98 hours. It took me 98 hours, blood, sweat and tears to finally win. I've had to sacrifice several relationships with family and friends, I failed school and got fired from my job. But in the end, it was all worth it. All the 30 fucking kudos. All the beans. All the wooo woooo's. And all the falling guys. Fuck, those falling fucking guys. Especially now when the game is free to play and everyone I know, EVERYONE, can go through the pain and suffering, completely free of charge. A special thanks to my husband, my boyfriend and our kids. I couldn't have done it without you. Signing out and uninstalling, yours truly, Alice

If you've ever played Shower with your Dad Simulator - it's nothing like that game but incredible nonetheless.
Picture this: Joe Biden takin' a steamy shower and all's of a suddens he drops a hot deuce and it gets caught in the ole shower drain.
That's fall guys.
You're having a great time and somebody grabs you and you fall off a ledge.
It's nothing serious, though.
It's not like hunting deer in the woods and alls of a suddens a wolf comes up and bites your neck and you become a vampire-wolf.
It's more like eating a big box of cheese balls and the mailman comes over and slaps your ass a little bit.
It's like watching Rosie O'Donnell on the View talk about politics for 5 minutes.
It's like eating a chocolate cake and then a rainbow of leprechauns comes and attacks you before you get to the pot of gold.
Just play it.

[h1] Honest Review [/h1] 
[u](Review written after 99 hours spent)[/u]
The game was a lot of fun when it first came out as everyone was new to it.
The current state of the game however despite all the changes they have made can be quite stale given how competitive the player base has gotten due to what feels like an aging player base.

That being said! The game has made many improvements since launch!
Fixing bugs, and hacker issues, and finally has what I always wanted, which was a way to play with more than 4 friends at a time, and with multiple different possible game modes.

[h1] Lots of bad UX: [/h1]
[hr][/hr]
[list]

I'm still not sure whether I recommend this game or not but for now, I am going to stick with recommended. Fall Guys is a fun game especially with friends but due to needing a specific amount of players in a lobby (Note that I play in SEA servers or the equivalent of it in the game), certain gamemodes are just not playable unless we wait in the loading screen for 10 minutes or more per attempt so we're stuck with the regular gamemode which even that still takes a few minutes from time to time. 

The gameplay itself is smooth and challenging so whenever you win a game, a rush of adrenaline comes to you and makes your victory even more impactful(that or I'm just a bad player heh)

I genuinely believe Fall Guys is a fun game if we are able to play it the way we want and not face the limitations I listed down. But still take my review with a grain of salt and try it out for yourself if you're really interested.

Fall Guys: Ultimate Knockout may be adorable, silly, and simple to learn, but that doesn't mean it's a low-stakes game. Despite the party game vibe, it's still a battle royale. For most of the match I'm content to goof around, take reckless chances, and stop to celebrate with emotes before crossing the finish line. Getting ragdolled or shoved out of contention usually just makes me laugh. But as the end of the final round approaches I'm suddenly taking things seriously as hell. I may be a bean wearing a frilly pink tutu, but I want to win.
   Overall it's a good and fun game.

I wrote out two complete stories about random characters I made up but I didn't feel they conveyed the emotion I wanted to put into this review. So instead I will just put it in words:
I came across this game when it was on sale for $10, an insanely good deal for how well made this game is. I took the offer and began playing with friends, it was a great experience. However, I cannot lie when I say there is a lack of boobs in this game and I am extremely disappointed. I don't know why they thought it would be a good idea to release this game without them when they are base feature for almost every modern game. I play games based on lust because it gives me energy. It is quite disturbing seeing the thing I most enjoy in video games being absent, I've had nightmares for about a month now. I just can't bring myself to give this game a good review, even if it was one of the best party games I have ever played.
Sorry I had to come back a year later because I remembered how much I hate this game.

Fall Guys is that one game I come back to because I want to give it another chance, thinking I'll enjoy it, but I really never do. 

It's far too easy to mess other players up which constantly leads to people failing to qualify, at which point they decide to start messing around with others in future games which creates this weird cycle where you'll constantly get people who just stand there trying to stop you from qualifying.

You repeatedly see the same courses and even in later rounds the game you play is usually just a slightly more difficult version of one you've already played 100 times. Not only that, but the same gimmicks are used over and over, you'd think with the seasons introducing some new courses that you'd see fresh mechanics and obstacles often, but you just see the same ones plastered across every new course.

I regret spending my money on this game, it would be far better as a F2P game where you could purchase some outfits and different cosmetics for real money, instead they chose to sell the currency to you in a game you've already had to pay for, which almost feels insulting, although it isn't too difficult to earn.

Fall guys was a fantastic game and i had tons of fun with it. But it is contuinuously getting worse. Especially the last update introduced so many new bugs that it's just not fun anymore.

-insane amounts of bodyblock
[strike]-stumbling is so random: sometimes you don't fall down when you land from a height, sometimes you touch something with your arm and you're rolling on the ground for 10 seconds[/strike]
[strike]-not spectating teammates after you die/qualify[/strike]
[strike]-buggy annoying sound whenever someone qualifies[/strike]
[strike]-desync between your character and the rest of the game (your position compared to other players/moving obstacles is different than what you see on screen)[/strike]
[strike]-collision check moved to serverside -> you die randomly when you're not hit on your screen but for the server[/strike]
-you get thrown out as a squad although you actually had the position to qualify
-you don't get thrown out but still don't spawn in the next round
[strike]-points in duos are completely bugged and random sometimes[/strike]

the playerbase isn't doing the game any better either:

-grabbing can ruin your round completely while you can barely do anything against it
-in squad rounds there are always guys waiting till the last second to reach the finish so you have to wait like forever

All in all a once great game that has gone downhill recently. I just hope they're gonna improve on some of that stuff, so i can enjoy it again.

EDIT 05.12.:
With the new season updates, a lot of the bugs from above were fixed (crossed out now)

Idk what exactly was changed about collision and stumbling, but playing just feels smoother again. It was an update for the better and i have now changed my review to positive. Also the new levels and skins are great.

However, there are also bugs in this update, the two most notable are the Kudos disappearing and randomly changing numbers and that you can bug out the pipes that are new introduced and then be stuck till the round ends. I hope they are fixed soon!

EDIT 22.12.:
The bug regarding Kudos is fixed and I haven't seen the one with the pipes in a while either, so good job an that!
Also i found out more about the bug where the squad is thrown out: When several squads tie on the last place for qualification, only the one that made the points first is gonna qualify, as if they were not tied.

Great concept and great selection of mini games and character customisation, however many of the games need to be re-worked either due to bugs or latency issues. for example Button Bashers has many latency issues where one player will land on a button however the other player is rewarded with the point. other examples of this are hoopsie daisy/ hoopsie legend. 
other issues i've encountered are objects not coming into contact with character yet character is thrown off the stage sometimes meaning elimination.
as a party game with friends this can be a lot of fun however on your own this game can be a very frustrating experience especially when some players are toxic enough to stand at the end of stages and push others off, or try to ruin someones run. some players also stand at the end of stages showing off emotes with no major time penalty (besides for a very long 15 seconds end of stage count down), holding up the players waiting to move on to the next game. some players even target one person simply for the costume they have on which can ruin a gaming experience.
over all great concept, still needs work.

I started this game after many months just because I saw that Season 5 had been released. I downloaded the update and found there was a limited time event to join. So I selected that and clicked Play.

Unfortunately, the same problem that led me away from the game was still there.

The screen with the guy falling and the message 'Waiting for players' is frustrating.

I waited for an interminable time before it said that 'no player available'.

I then selected all available 4 episodes including the main show. But again I waited for many minutes and it still said that there were no players available.

Of the 12.5 hours that I have supposedly 'played' this game. 6 hours have been spent watching the fall guy falling down with 'waiting for players to join' screen.

The developers should have an option for fewer players to join. And/or for an option to select the level of our choice. There have been many levels I never played because it autoselects the levels and doesn't give me an option to choose.

While I absolutely love the moments while it actually worked, overall I have learned that I can't spend half my gametime just waiting for players to join.

[h1]Fun with friends or over a coffee break[/h1]
This is kind of a TV show about a bunch of jellybeany runners, competing in a set of colorful elimination games until the best (or luckiest) competitor wins the crown. It's quite anticipating to see how you as a player fare against 59 others, who are doing (trying) their best to make it to the next goal. Maneuvering and observation are the key skills to make the best out of the rounds but luck also comes to play at times, when moving obstacles and crowding become a dealing matter.

The playful mood and colorful aesthetic make for a wholesome setting, contrasted by slapstick factor when moving obstacles catches you off-guard or at your poor timing. Such high-pace competition paired with unpredictability that could turn you to a rolling ragdoll makes the gameplay often exciting and anticipating but also occasionally agitating. The first few days, I've enjoyed progressing, failing and winning races at the literal rush of the moment with fellow players; afterwards, I got sneakily pushed off the edge by particularly competitive opponents more than a few times, getting eliminated as a result.

The constant updates and regular daily features proves that its community is well alive. There are a wide range of cosmetics to come by and daily tasks that reward you with currencies and milestone assets. Unless you wear stock cosmetics or features from other games, no player will be alike.

This dopamine-infused, mass obstacle course game has got its Nintendo stamp all over. Although there is a large variety of levels to get through and the competition getting unpredictable, you might feel it starting to get repetitive after a few days. I have to concur with issues of varying loading times and RNG level selection bog down the momentum of the exciting, competing sessions.

At least, I can't help but come back to this over a coffee break to get a change of gaming and some fierce, social interaction without words. And yes, I once managed to be the last guy falling.

After coming back from the first season, all I can say is... am I in a fever dream?
Are these really humans I'm playing with? Why does the second round end with 20 people, but the final round starts with 3? Where did the other 17 go?

I feel like 95% of the players in my games are bots. They don't play like humans (even children and toddlers act differently than these "players'). No one is wearing any crown outfits, instead everyone is wearing (without fail) a random assortment of kudos/standard outfits, and virtually NEVER a complete set.

It's bizarre, and it's not the game it used to be. I expected long queue times, not whatever feverish nightmare this game currently is.
Does anyone even still play this? Genuinely asking

The game-show concept here is great. Some of the rounds even live up to that concept. Most of the rounds I played just weren't very fun, though. Team rounds were largely pointless with no real communicative capacity (and are some of the most poorly controlling mini-games, too) and many of the rounds fail to deliver the goofy mayhem promised in trailers and the sillier games instead just being mildly frustrating until you learn the patterns or else having fairly safe pseudo-strategies that will see you through nearly every single time.

At it's best, the rounds are either wild and goofy or surprisingly tense  and competitive given the intentionally awkward controls and the bright aesthetic. When the game spends its time at either of these two extremes, it excels and it is a lot of fun. But it just doesn't get their often enough and you can spend match after match having a properly mediocre time--especially since a lot of the better rounds are further in meaning you'll slog through many of the least fun games over and over and over again whether you qualify for later rounds or not.

I love this idea, and I'd love to see more of this sort of multiplayer experience. I can't recommend this particular game, though.

[h1] Video Games [/h1]
 
While Fall Guys: Ultimate Knockout isn't nearly as popular as it was around the time it launched, it still remains a perfect video game for what it sets out to accomplish. Its presentation, gameplay, low skill floor and price tag make it accessible to anyone who'd want to give it a try. If you're looking for something refreshing to play with a group of friends, even those who might not be big on video games, then look no further. 


Gameplay-wise, it is the best Wipeout or Ninja Warrior game (n?)ever made. You know, those shows where people have to beat an obstacle course in order to win the prize money? Here it’s a bit different, with up to 60 players thrown into a match, consisting of several rounds. At the end of every round, those who fail to complete the objective in time are eliminated. Not every round is an obstacle course however, but can be anything from a vast plethora of minigames spread into six different categories. For example, Race rounds will always task you with reaching the finish line of the course before a certain number of players manage to. Survival rounds will require you to not get eliminated before a certain number of players does, or a timer runs out. These are then further differentiated by themes and obstacles. One Survival round might have you balance atop of an ever-moving platform, dodging projectiles launched at you, while another will place you in an arena with three giant Rhinos attempting to knock you out. Team rounds, which require you to work with random players towards a common goal to prevent your entire team from being eliminated are all about scoring points, but can either be a game of basketball, football (the soccer kind) or collecting as high of a number of eggs as possible. In the main game mode, a match must always start with a Race and end with a Finale – the most suspenseful, final round of the match, usually a Race that only one player can win or a Survival round that keeps going until the last man standing. Other game modes, both fixed and rotating, focus on specific categories or levels themselves. There are also custom matches you can make for you and your friends.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2618963922

Even if all rounds across a category follow a certain pattern, none ultimately feel the same. Additional obstacles will sometimes appear on maps they were previously absent from, so the game can still throw you a curveball even when you think you have them all memorised. 

Still, some are clearly better designed than others. Door Dash, a Race round, is a course consisting entirely out of doors. Some of these are openable, while the others aren’t – with there being no way of telling between the two until you try going through them. It almost completely eradicates the momentum of the match. If you go for an openable door consistently enough, you’ll qualify. If you don’t, tough luck. Other levels that solely consist of multitudes of the same obstacle have a similar effect, though none are as bad as Door Dash.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2618967222

The controls are quite tight due to how limited they are. You can jump, grab (players, ledges, objects and some objectives) and dive, so the game requires a total of three buttons to play – excluding movement. A controller is ideal, but the keyboard and mouse perform almost just as well.

Progression feels good, but it could feel better. Winning a round will net you a Crown, the game’s ’’premium’’ currency awarded solely through wins or milestones in the current Season’s battle pass-like progression, called Fame levels – limited to 50 per Season and increased by XP, which is awarded for each match you play. Each Crown you acquire also increases your overall player rank, which awards you cosmetics upon leveling up and is separate from your Fame level. Besides Crowns, there are Kudos, a second currency awarded at certain Fame levels, as well as upon completion of a match regardless of whether you won or not. Kudos can also be purchased through microtransactions, in bundles as costly as $50, more than twice the game’s price. While the game isn’t by any means stingy with its rewards, the progression does feel a bit staggered and the inclusion of microtransactions can’t help but make me think of some marketing analyst or currency designer figuring out how to optimize it best to incentivise a purchase. Even when they aren’t intrusive, they’re there for a reason.

Your rewards can be spent in the store for cosmetic items. Some cost Kudos, some cost Crowns. There’s a fixed number of items that can be displayed in the store at a time and they reset once a day. Simple as. Customization options for your Fall Guy are quite varied and some visually striking combinations are possible, even without playing much.

Visually, the game is a colorful joy to look at, with the audio making it all the more appealing. The Fall Guys make cute ’’oofs“ and other sounds when they collide with each other, and scream of excitement when an obstacle launches them into the air – all of it heightened by a groovy, bass driven soundtrack. It just oozes fun.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2618970077

Performance wise, the game ran great on max settings, at a steady 60 FPS. However, the animation LOD distance wasn’t that great, as players and obstacles further away would be running at a notably lower framerate. I don’t know if this is simply the way the game’s optimised, or something affected by the limitations of my specs. Weirdly enough, the game would sometimes drop down to 30 FPS while waiting in the lobby or the post-match recap.
 
Reviewed on the following system:

[table][tr][td]CPU [/td][td]AMD Ryzen 5 3600 3.6GHz[/td][/tr][tr][td]GPU[/td][td]GeForce GTX 1050Ti[/td][/tr][tr][td]RAM [/td][td]16GB[/td][/tr][/table]

While the game’s current player numbers are a far cry from what it once had, it still maintains a healthy population, both on Steam and outside of it, thanks to cross-play. I wholeheartedly hope that Mediatonic can keep Fall Guys: Ultimate Knockout in such a state, as it’s a fun game that truly anyone can play. Even if you don’t end up winning, the little animation your Fall Guy does during the post-match summary shows that he’s had a lot of fun even participating, just as you will. Here’s to hoping it can keep going strong in the years to come, at least as long until there’s a worthy successor.

Putting this at the top since I think it will help a lot of people: 

Mouse/Keyboard: The BIGGEST TIP I have is to bind your left mouse click to DIVE and your right mouse click to GRAB. You do not use your mouse click buttons for anything else so it makes dive and grab SUPER easy to quickly press, which will make a huge difference for you. Left click is easier for me to press repeatedly, so I chose dive for that one and grab for the right click because it's not as often. You'll be diving way more than grabbing. 

If you are playing on CONTROLLER, it almost feels like cheating cause it is SO much easier. Only thing I hate is you have to micromanage the camera angles a little more for some of the courses that twist and turn, but I got the hang of it. 

OH and hold down the GRAB button when you are making a jump that you're not sure if you will make it or not- YOU CAN GRAB ONTO LEDGES. Wish I knew that sooner. When you first start out it might seem super hard but it gets super easy and fun once you get the hang of it. 

--------------------------------------------
Review:
It's like Wipe Out, the tv show. You gather "fame" to level up. You can dive and also grab onto other players to sabotage them, which is a lot of fun. The courses are a lot of fun and there are a ton of them. The cosmetic items are super cute, and the ones you earn in game are way better than the ones you buy through DLC imo. You get a daily random of selection of items (refreshed every day) to buy through their store using crowns or kuddos(?), both of which you earn by playing the game. They have events once a week I think? Not sure how often they are, but there's been a ton of them where you queue up for a special game that gives you a special currency to buy special items with. I love it because while the game hardly ever gets boring, the special events like that give you extra incentive to want to keep coming back. Ton of achievements through steam too. 
----------------------------------------

Here are some more random tips:

If you're playing on a team for tails, please do not steal your team members tails. Working against your own team members is counter-productive. At first I was thinking, oh okay maybe they feel super confident in being able to keep the tail or something? But almost every time they lose the tail IMMEDIATELY after stealing it lol which is hilarious, embarrassing for them, and frustrating for the whole team. Steal the OPPOSITE TEAMS tails.

If you're on a team for JINXED and you have the cooties on you, please spread the cooties onto THE OTHER COLORED TEAM, not your OWN team. XD

The game is great. That was until Epic Games has decided to make this experience "better". I might sound a bit salty, but it just shames to see a micro transaction system be put in place, with all of the old skins re-ranked. The crowns which were free from micro-transactions have been  replaced with Show Bucks, which is basically Fall Guys version of V-bucks. The game has lost its charm from being a micro transaction free battle royal. Spitting on the people who originally bought the game.

However, all isn't that bad. I believe that Epic Games will make more and better updates than Mediatonic. And I also believe that they will drastically bring the player base back up!

Unfortunately, as a person who originally bought Fall Guys, I strongly despise Mediatonics decision to leave the Fall Guys project. And my negatives for the "New" Fall Guys out rule the positives.

As of writing this review, I have played about 15 hours, and I've reached the final probably more than 2 dozen times. I've never won though, because sometimes I messed up and sometimes I just didn't have the luck needed. It's annoying to lose a final, but I get over it in like 2 minutes.

It's fun if you play it casually (like I do). Just don't take it too seriously. Your skill is how consistently you are able to reach the final, not how many times you win. Winning is hugely dependent on luck. This is my opinion, at least.

The Season rewards can be achieved without playing much. The game motivates you to play a little daily, as daily objectives are quite easy to achieve, and give fame (for season rewards) and crown parts (main currency in the game along with a purchasable currency). Shouldn't take more than 15-30 minutes for a decent player to get the daily rewards.

There is no battle pass type system either (yet, at least). Which is a big plus, I think.

You don't need to have experience in 3D platformers to do well in the game. The controls are pretty simple, and the game plays well with both KB+M (my way) and controller (which I've seen people do well with).

There are certain levels that are well made and genuinely fun, some others which aren't. Some are downright luck based. But overall it's alright.

Team rounds are very much luck dependent. The quality of your team mainly decides whether you'll qualify to the next round or not.

You can play in a group with friends/family, which is IMO the preferable way to play. The above mentioned team events might become easier if your group is good. Solo is fun too, of course.

There is a main show, and some other shows. I found games pretty quickly (usually 1-3 minutes) in both the main show and the current time limited show (Squad Celebration).

It's a recommendation because the game is fun, and it respects your time, unlike the other Battle Royale games I've seen.

Thanks for reading, and I hope this review helps you decide.

Edit: First victory after 23 hours of playtime!

Throw in the long loading and waiting times between games and what could be a quick 15 minutes of fun, becomes a bit of a snooze fest.

Fall Guys: Ultimate Knockout touts itself as a fun battle royale style type of gameshow with both single player and team match modes. The fun stops there though.

This game employs a (horrible) EULA and Privacy policy that seriously should make you question intent.

The EULA states, amongst other things, that you give the game company a world wide license to them and their partners of any content you, for instance, stream or upload somewhere. In other words, they're free to benefit from, for instance, a review or impressions video you make of the game. Furthermore, the privacy policy logs all your interactions (in-game actions and what they call "patterns") by posting data to them. The info they collect may also be shared with third parties like holding companies or other business entities to name a few. You can read them both [url=https://fallguys.com/eula-combined]here[/url] and [url=https://fallguys.com/fall-guys-privacy-policy]here[/url].

This is just a tip of the iceberg. They also collect personal data about you from third party platforms you use, i.e Steam or Playstation. I've rarely seen such anti-consumer agreements which completely engulfs whatever privacy the user have left into oblivion. You can't opt-out of it either. 

Data collection is nothing new of course, same goes with games installing software you absolutely don't want on your computer (denuvo and easy-anti cheat amongst others). Most people sadly don't care, but for us that do this is important. Fall Guys is by no mark of the mile unique - there are many other games on Steam that carry this practice. This is about taking a stance against anti-consumer behaviour and giving a straight message to the game companies what they're doing is not okay - one game at a time.

If you want to play Fall Guys you must accept . Some people may be fine with this, but I am not.

Unfortunately not my cup of tea. At first I thought this would be a nice casual party game, but you will quickly notice it is not. Nothing that a little time and effort can't fix, but I don't play multiplayer games anymore to avoid having to spend that much time in a game.

On some games that is not an issue, but in this game you will quickly notice that even as a beginner you will get packed into games with tons more advanced players. This creates early knock outs so at first getting knocked out in the first or second rounds will probably happen often. To top that off it feels pretty slow paced (expected faster gameplay). To me it seems a bit dull, as you will be either watching or backing out of the game and searching for your next game. Fortunately there seem to be plenty players so waiting for a game doesn't take that long, but it feels kinda dull having to get good, or spend as much on the lobby screen as in the game.

This is probably solved by just improving after some games, and getting to know the maps. However I cannot say this for certain as I already noticed this isn't for me and therefor will not be playing any further.

PS: they have also been lazy on the naming system. You can only randomize, not even remotely pick something you like. I know they apparently had users abuse being able to input names, but seriously, just ban specific names from being used rather than picking your own name completely :S

This game was overall fun at first. The maps and ideas it had were great. I used to hop on this game with some of my friends almost every night around the time of its release. Over the past year however, I took an extended break from this game until recently, where I decided that I wanted to give the new season a try. However no matter what I do, I am unable to even start the game as it gives me a "Failed to login, please check your connection" error. My first thought was to restart, and do all the basic IT stuff (reinstalling the game, checking integrity of files, make sure my internet wasn't crapping itself, etc.). I was surprised when I booted them game again and still had no luck. It was then I decided to try port forwarding using a tutorial I found online. That didn't work either. (Servers are also online so it isn't that). I should also mention that I have never once cheated in this game as I saw some posts about that as well. At this point i'm at a loss, and I really don't care to try anymore for this 10 dollar game. Unless someone has a be-all end-all fix for me to try, this game isn't worth my time. If you get this error as well, I would recommend a refund :)

I recommend this game on sale to anyone who enjoys 3D physics platforming, is comfortable with PvP of sorts, and has friends to play it with. Without friends to play with, make sure you really love the core gameplay and are good with the level & cosmetics variety (more on that later).
Here is what you need to know about items and such:
?The only Battle Pass type system is leveling up with Fame (XP) during the current season (months long), which gives the player a variety of rewards when progressing through each season-specific level, up to 50. No purchasable Battle Pass. It took me ~20 hours of gameplay to reach level 50. Fame only unlocks season levels, which earn cosmetics, Kudos currency, or crowns and fame is not used directly to purchase anything.
?3 daily reward/achievements consist of one way to get Fame (becomes crown shards when max level in season) and 2 ways to get crowns shards.  Each one ranges from around 6 to 12 shards, with higher ones being more difficult.  60 shards will turn into a crown. Nice way to get crowns without ever winning a solo game. Shards instead of a crown can be won by winning a trio or 4 player squad shows as well.
-After 30 hours, I started to notice that the occasional color, upper, and face cosmetics will very similar to others. So that adds to some of the bloat of more common cosmetics to buy.
?Crowns earned from wins unlock rewards independent of the battle pass (not sure if they reset every season?), and crowns can also be used for certain generally more rare store items.
?Kudos credits are earned alongside fame, or credits can be purchased. Credits are used to buy various cosmetics or taunts from a store that changes item types about once a day.
+Link your Amazon Prime account to get extra credits.

As for the game itself:
?A show consists of one or more levels, and each level will eliminate ~20% of the players. The final level will only have 1 winner.
+Solid variety of different levels.
?Each level has one of these conditions: Reach the end area, 2-3 teams compete and 1 team is eliminated, or free for all survival to not get eliminated (e.g. fall into slime).
?Groups of players can team up in a unique show type, but will only win crown shards instead of a whole crown if the group wins (I havent tried this mode)
+Controls are simple and well done, as there is just the right amount of a little physics chaos and control. Grab, jump, or dive are the main things you can do.
?Look, feel, and sound fits the game but is nothing special.
?Matchmaking in the morning, day, or night has been decent. I dont think I've waited more than a minute to join a show.
?Grabbing other players may be considered a jerk move. Not sure how much these result in users getting reported, but I can imagine someone salty doing that.
?I havent seen any cheaters or totally suspect physics yet. Not sure if the server authoritative or not (doubt it).
?Even if I get tired of it eventually like Rocket League, I can see myself returning to the game every so often for future shows & seasons.

Outside of the game:
+There is cross platform play support.
-The game uses Easyanticheat. I havent had any system issues with this. Even though my network router initially blocked communication to the EAC domain for a while, the game worked for at least a while before unblocking it. Mess with this at your own risk, as circumventing it or cheating could get you banned.
-The dev is owned by Epic Games. The last time Epic bought a studio (Psyconix of Rocket League fame), they turned the game into F2P, the game could only be acquired new thru EGS, and the prices of prior DLC content that were brought back to sell on EGS became many times more expensive.
?The game uses Epic Online Services, and requires either an Epic account or an SSO account.  By the latter, I mean if you had Rocket League on Steam, and used Steam to Epic SSO, then you don't have to create an account manually, and that same SSO login will be used for Fall Guys.  I didn't have a problem with doing that myself.  Just know that your Epic account name will be auto assigned. I have no idea if it can be changed if you go through the complete registration process online, which is not required by Steam to Epic SSO.

Fall Guys is a game that seeks to imitate reality shows like Wipeout, wherein groups of 60 players compete to pass rounds of minigames to try to be the one winner.

The game has a colorful neon aesthetic, which naturally draws the attention of kids. The games are all very engaging and reminiscent of basic childhood games like Rob the Nest (Egg Scramble), Virus Tag (Jinxed), and Tail Tag. Some are simple "race to the end"-type games, and others are team-based. Winning a whole game is quite difficult, and provides a sense of repeated challenge that some children may enjoy, but that others may find frustrating.

The game controls are simplistic and accessible: you can move around, jump, dive, and grab. That last mechanic allows players to grab onto ledges and even other players, which (when done with the intent of making them lose) is called griefing. Although being griefed is somewhat uncommon, it can cause your child to lose unjustly when it does happen. Talk with your child about dealing with griefers online!

Overall, this is a perfect introduction into online video games for a child, and a blast to play for all ages.

Fall Guys is a very fun & chaotic game that can be enjoyed by people of all ages. It stands out among other Battle Royale games for it's family friendly approach. Unlike other similar games in the genre, such as Fortnite & Among Us, which rely on weapons, complex puzzles and death, Fall Guys is simply silly slapstick and so will appeal to all ages and is highly unlikely to offend anyone. It can be a bit frustrating at times, especially when you're so close to winning an episode, only to lose it at the last second, but that's nothing new with Battle Royale games. Plus when you actually win an episode (I've won 5 in my 25 hours of gameplay), it's a feeling like no other.

The game is a good distraction from the outside world if needed, and the regular updates keep things fresh

Fall Guys is chock-full of zany platforming fun.  Every bounce and near-miss was amusing and funny rather than frustrating.  There's a lot of variety in their different level/activity types, though I feel like it would greatly benefit from level "chunks" that are randomized, Rogue-like-style.  I also think Overwatch-style replays would be fantastic in this game, especially for the final crown levels.

While I do recommend the game, it's one of those games that you play for 1-2 hours a night, rather than binging it in a weekend.
Lots of fun and it's very easy to get into.

I've spent a ton of time playing this game, so I want to do my best to give an honest review of the game and do it justice.

A basic explanation on what the game is, would be a colorful and eye-popping battle royal style game that includes a multitude of different rounds to play - including solo race rounds, puzzle rounds, and skill based rounds. Team rounds are also a staple of the game play, pairing you up with random players in your lobby to work towards a common goal. However, there is only one crown, and therefore can only be one winner! In some cases there can be multiple winners, but for this to happen you have to have cooperation with the rest of the lobby and some skill in order to time out rounds.

The game play feels choppy at times, is the best way I can describe it. The crowd physics in the game, regarding interacting with other players through running into their character or grabbing them for different purposes, has from day one been an ongoing issue. While some games you can play with no issues and great server connection, other games will have you frustrated, especially in game modes requiring the grabbing aspect to either steal tails, hold Pegwins or trying to fight back against someone trying to grief you. I feel like it'll forever be an issue in the game, because the problem seems to be much deeper than just a simple patch can fix. I understand that this issue can be a deal breaker for new players, and I want to reiterate that it will become a problem for every player at some point.

For a game that looks colorful and fun and simple to play, there is a strong competitive player base that makes the games much more difficult for unsuspecting players. There are some people who will be able to pick up the game quickly and roll with the punches, but for most players there is a learning curve involved. I'm currently, as of this review, still under 600 crowns in total with 900 hours of playtime. I personally enjoy playing the game with friends, however, and spend a lot of time in game modes such as Squads Show and 2-3 man squads. This isn't a game that I think you can solely play competitively, and if you're going to continue coming back to the game you should find a way to have fun while playing! That can be any reason - grief other players, play with friends, or helping other players win. There's an amazing scene of streamers and players on Twitch that really got me hooked on the game, and I encourage anyone looking for other players to check out someone they like on that site! Personally I recommend DjBigRuss and CrazyyTrainn, but there are plenty of people to chat and play with!

Overall, it's a game - there will be plenty of people who enjoy it, and many others who dislike it. There's plenty of players online however, and finding a match doesn't take very long at all. With all the different levels and variations of those levels, along with an interactive media team and a development team that brings new content to the game as soon as they can. I recommend giving the game a chance at some point, if you're not willing to spend $20 for it then wait until it goes on sale. It's a wonderful game and I've met some wonderful people I don't think I would have met without this game, and it'll forever be a game that I have a ton of love for.

Fall Guys is an enjoyable game for both newbies and pros alike. Although it is a mass elimination style game, it's fun regardless of whether you win or lose. Wins feel more earned than random, and you feel accomplished when you get better and better the more you play, finding yourself progressing through to the further levels. The goofy environment of Fall Guys gives it a lighthearted that's easy to love, and the controls feel responsive and satisfying. 

There are always players that will ruin your fun, such as those who intentionally grab and attempt to push you off a ledge to grief you, but the developers actively discourage this type of gameplay. It's great to see them so involved with their fans, respond to feedback with surveys, and generally are actively always making new levels and costumes to keep the game interesting. I've played since Season 1, and feel like those coming into the game now are spoiled with the variety they have these days. 

Although the game has trouble holding most people's attention for very long, I'd say it's 100% worth a try to play with friends at the very least. Run around with friends on voice chat and have fun laughing at each other.
Absolutely fun to play with friend xD

[b]+[/b]

I put off purchasing it as I missed the initial hype but picked it up a little after season 5 started and queues are still fast with plenty of active players. There are lots of cosmetics to collect in the shop which rotates every day, earning the credits & crowns to purchase them isn't [i]too[/i] grindy and sooner or later you'll get a decent stash. 
The events usually give you some time to complete and you don't have to 100% the goals to collect everything [i](thank goodness, squad wins can be the most frustrating thing).[/i]
There is a great rotation of mini-games and 4 game modes to choose from, which changes every few days. Plus there is an option to host or join games with your friends. [i](I recommend joining the official Discord server if you want to team up but don't have people to play with - link on the Fall Guys website).[/i]
There is no communication between players in-game. I am most certainly putting this in the good points side of things as several of the games really pit you against each other or make you rely on others to get through quickly.

[b]-[/b]

The music is very catchy but repetitive and there are quite a few noisy emotes which get spammed often so turning down the sound and popping on a podcast/your own music is best if you have a longer play session. 
You do sometimes meet trolls who will wait out the timer before crossing the finish line but it's not overly common.



I recommend watching videos/reading guides to learn the little tricks and shortcuts if you want to give yourself an edge/consistently get to the finals & win. 
There is a grabbing players mechanic so be prepared for hugs & wrestling matches, sometimes tactical, sometimes just for the sake of it. Be wary near edges!

Overall, it's an enjoyable little game to play solo or with friends.

Unless you're playing with friends for laughs, this can be a very frustrating game to play if you're trying to win.

It's a two edge sword, on the one hand if you want a free, don't care, mindless game then it's perfect. You can troll others, try to play what is effectively interactive 'marbles' as you see on Twitch, mixed with the battlegrounds type game of PUBG.

On the other hand, if you're playing repeatedly in trying to win, well only 25% of the playerbase has won a game, but over 90% of the player base has hit other players, or done so while rolling around. That should tell you a lot.

It's enjoyably brainless, but that only lasts so long by yourself.

Fall Guys is definitely a fun game, however, I genuinely believe it reaches its true potential when you have friends to also jump in on it to try and win that crown! I am not sure to why but I have always preferred playing the game with friends when compared to being on my own.

However, it is a wonderful package of multiple interesting levels to make it feel fresh and slightly challenging. The addition of new seasons is also a nice touch and helps keep the game fresh without making the player feel a constant repetition which will led them to lose interest.

Overall, I would say its worth picking up if you have friends to play it with!

Fall Guys had a rough start. Unstable servers and people cheating to win. About a year later I picked it up again and I must say it really has improved a lot. I honestly don't have any issues which cheaters anymore and the servers don't crash on me anymore.

It's also getting more and more stages to play so it feels refreshing to play a few rounds every day.  The events for certain skins are also really fun. Sure there could still be some improvements like personal usernames or maybe a way to trade in skins you don't want. But I feel like they listen to their community and are aiming to make it as fun as possible. I'm interested to see how Fall Guys will keep evolving!
